tickets.description:
Hiya,

Nice simple one. When the browser window is closed, 
the toolbar window is not. This may not matter 
visually, as the window vanishes due to it being 
nested. However, the window still exists, having not 
been deleted. The result is that if you open a few 
windows and close them, the toolbars are still hanging 
around the system taking up resources \(for the Wimp\).

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=453739

As I understand the gui code, the solution is as follows:

1\. Replace the call to gui\_window\_hide\(\) in gui\_poll\(\) with
browser\_window\_destroy\(\)
\(and remove gui\_window\_hide\(\), which is no longer needed\).

2\. Add wimp\_delete\_window\(\) calls for the window and
toolbars to gui\_window\_destroy\(\).
posts.author: bursa
posts.subject: #1 Windows are being leaked

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=453739

Should be fixed in latest checkin.

posts.subject: #1 Windows are being leaked

Hiya,

Another nice easy one...

browser\_window\_gadget\_click can return with an 
invalid return code. The end of the routine is dropped 
off without any return value being provided. This 
causes the Select clicks on links to do nothing.

Solution: stick return 0; at the end of the routine.

tickets.summary: Absolute positioning  broken in new version?

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=906191
Originator: NO

This is caused by r3893. NetSurf now matches the specification for CSS length parsing whereas before it was more lenient. 

The page contains the likes of top:45; which is invalid.

Looks like we'll need a rendering quirk here, once we get some idea of page quirkiness from the HTML parser.

When visiting www.standaard.be I see the following in the log file:

\--8<--
content/fetchers/fetch\_curl.c fetch\_curl\_abort 647: fetch 0x3ee5fc18, url 'http://212.113.82.167/dcs5xe6zko8edgcm6fgwmoan0\_8f9w/njs.gif?dcsredirect=1&dcsredirect=1&dcsredirect=1&dcsredirect=1&dcsredirect=1&dcsredirect=1&dcsredirect=1&dcsredirect=1&dcsredirect=1&dcsredirect=1&dcsredirect=1&dcsuri=/nojavascript&WT.js=No'
content/fetchcache.c fetchcache\_redirect 896: Too many nested redirects
content/content.c content\_reformat 818: 0x3ee67ffc http://www.standaard.be/
riscos/plotters.c ro\_plot\_clip 374: bad clip rectangle 24 113 29 114
riscos/plotters.c ro\_plot\_clip 374: bad clip rectangle 24 107 29 108
riscos/plotters.c ro\_plot\_clip 374: bad clip rectangle 24 101 29 102
\--8<--

I was told on IRC that "bad clip rectangle" isn't something which is supposed to happen so therefore this report.

I can not reproduce this when saving the webpage on disc \(either as 1 file, either via full-save\).  Perhaps it has something to do with "Too many nested redirects" error message given just before ?

Full log file attached.

John.

David Pilling has said about Ovation Pro: "This is not a 
'new bug' this is a shortcoming in the way OP selects a 
variation on a font. It is something that has dragged on

then another, etc. no one is ever happy.

You can select the exact font family member you want in 
OP, just makes things a little more difficult."

tickets.description:
Dragging a file from a Sunfish mount to NetSurf always results in the error "Sorry, NetSurf was unable to display this page. Could not open file /Sunfish". The URL bar shows "file:///Sunfish\#::Mount.$/<path>" \(where <path> is the path of the file in the mount\). Removing the "\#" character and pressing Return loads the file correctly. Tested with build of 07 Mar 08 on an Iyonix, 128MB, RISC OS 5.11.

The "\#" character is not part of the filename sent by the Filer, but it is included when a Sunfish file name is canonicalised and at a guess, NetSurf ask for the file name to be canonicalised. After doing so, NetSurf should process the filename and replace "\#" by "%23" since "\#" is not a valid character in a base URL \(it introduces a fragment identifier\).
tickets.summary: Files from Sunfish: cause "not found" error

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=906191
Originator: NO

The percent encoding is fixed in SVN. However, the path translation requires an updated UnixLib, so won't appear fixed until this occurs on the autobuilder.

tickets.description:
r3857 on loading reported something wrong when loading default style sheets and then crash with a segfault stack frame address fffffff6\!\!\!\!\!\!\!\!\!

I tried a couple of times with the same result.

I then tried my normal 9 July version which tried to load and crashed - reporting no error. - looking at the log this was just another segfault. Since I have been using this 9 Jul 2007 version regularly for months, I deleted all copies of Netsurf from the machine in use and, over my local net tried the copy on one of my other machines - this crashed too\!

Running that copy on its own machine, however, ran perfectly - as I expected.

I copied this to the machine causing the problem - still segfaulting.

I rebooted and the 9 Jul version works seetly again.

I suspect that something rogue had happened due to previous activity using some other application/utility over the last few weeks since the last boot, however, as when I tried to shut down prior to reboot there were fatal errors in Minidisc, StrongED, etc.

While, therefore, it appears that the error may not actually be in Netsurf, I sort of suspect that there is something which it isn't or can't catch and recover from. Hence this bug report.

I wish I could offer more thoughts as this is the sort of bug that leaves me tearing my hair out\!\!

Keith Hopper
asgard@inspire.net.nz

tickets.description:
in ro\_uri\_message\_received \(uri.c\) the URI\_PROCESS\_ACK 
is being sent as an acknowledge rather than a reply. This means 
that the 'result' doesn't get properly sent back to the calling task 
and that the request doesn't get cleared from the chain \(uriinfo\). 

john.p.baker@bristol.ac.uk

When http://www.netsurf-browser.org/downloads/themes/ is opened in a NetSurf window, which is not wide enough to display the full width of the PNGs, a horizontal scroll bar appears, within the height of each PNG. Attempting to drag the scroll bar launches a download of the theme, instead of scrolling the PNG.

Re-sizing the window, by even a small amount, causes the scroll bars to be re-drawn below each PNG, and scrolling then works correctly.

Another re-draw problem is seen if you

1 re-size the window so that only the left half of a PNG is visible,
2 drag its scroll bar to the extreme right and
3 re-size the window to full width.

The scroll bar disappears, but the PNG remains half-width.

Tony

tickets.description:
If elements in a definition list do not have a terminator </dd> then each successive definition is indented to the right. A <dt> or <dd> should implicitly close an open <dt> or <dd> element and not implicitly open a new <dl>.

For an example see the index page for the html Basic manual on the RISC OS 3 PRM CD.

tickets.description:
Simple form with <select><option value="...">Option text</option>....
where some option text might be fairly long \(say 40 characters\) typically causes the displayed element to be too narrow to contain the selected option. The result is truncation of the selected option text.

This was seen with default font face and size \(homerton\) with NS 1.1 \(15 Oct 2007 23:00 r3633\).
mike.hobbs@antplc.com or mike@mhobbs.demon.co.uk

And while I'm entering this bug report I've noticed another input element size problem. The Summary input is showing the summary text of this bug where the caret will not move to the beginning of the text. It shows "lect menu size too small to contain all option tex" and the caret won't go any further left than between the truncated "e" and the "l". It does move to the end of the text. Further experimenting reveals that this condition is dependent on placing the caret within the text usint the mouse and then moving it left with cursor key. If the caret is moved to the end of the text and then left it will go all the way to the beginning.
Looks like there is a wrong calculation of the size of the rendered text under certain circumstances.

And, if the desktop is using system font the NS version details don't fit in the Version field of the Info window.

Netsurf requires the Drawfile module 
An old version of this can be downloaded from ...

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=906191

You shouldn't ever see that message. All versions of RISC OS later than \(and including\) 3.6 have the Drawfile module in ROM. RO 5.06 has version 1.52 in ROM so it sounds like it's been unplugged for some reason. 
Type \*unplug in a taskwindow. If DrawFile appears in the list, issue a \*rmreinit Drawfile.

233 StrongArm RiscPC, RO 3.7, 36+2MB

Dad@therpc.f9.co.uk

I need to set the Proxy Type setting to "NTLM authentication" to get web access and this works fine with NetSurf.

The trouble is it "forgets" this setting, in that the next time I run NetSurf the setting has changed to "Basic authentication".

NetSurf 1.2 \(GTK+\) on Fedora 7.

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=718847
Originator: YES

Changing line 169 of desktop/options.c \(version 1.2\) from:
\{ "http\_proxy\_auth", OPTION\_BOOL,    &option\_http\_proxy\_auth \},
to:
\{ "http\_proxy\_auth", OPTION\_INTEGER,    &option\_http\_proxy\_auth \},
fixes the problem.

I have a number of unix scripts and cgi wrappers that output text within <xmp></xmp> tags. However I found that such text is not handled by netsurf.  netsurf does not seem to see CHR$\(10\) as a line break and doesn't use a mono spaced font as browse etc do.

James

tickets.description:
Hello Netsurf Developers,

Since half October 2004 or so, ALL newer releases 
crash sooner or later while accessing the Drobe site 
\(www.drobe.co.uk\) on my RiscPC at work
and also on my Omega at home. What happens is that 
while loading some page on Drobe, Netsurf just 
disappears completely \(windows and iconbar icon\). No 
error message. There is no fixed reproducable pattern
before the error arises, but it always happens sooner 
or later \(mostly sooner\!\). Most other sites are OK. 
With every new release I was hoping that the problem 
was solved, because I could not think I was the
only one having this problem. Today \(07-12-04\) I 
downloaded the latest release again, but the problem 
is still there :-\(

I have attached a fresh copy of the stderr file 
produced after accessing the Drobe site anew. I 
noticed a Floating point exception message in the
error report.

Best regards.
Frits Polak

e-mail: fritspolak@hetnet.nl

tickets.description:
I don't know whether this is an actual bug, but it 
seems worth reporting.

I have two copies of Netsurf on my RPC at present:
'Test Build \(01 Jul 2004 23:30\)'
and
'Test Build \(03 Mar 2005 22:35\)'

The older one loads "instantly", and once loaded runs 
well and seems stable.
The later one \(which I believe is the latest\) takes 
three and a half minutes to load\! However, once 
loaded, it runs well, and seems stable.

Both versions have a file stderr in their folders. 
The July 2004 version's stderr is short:
desktop/netsurf.c netsurf\_init 62: version 'Test Build 
\(01 Jul 2004 23:30\)'
desktop/netsurf.c netsurf\_init 69: NetSurf on 
<riscos>, node <poolejpn.silver.ocn.ne.jp>, release 
<3.60>, version <2.02>, machine <arm-acorn>

riscos/gui.c ro\_gui\_check\_resolvers 375: 
Inet$Resolvers '203.139.161.40 203.139.160.74 '

The March 2005 version's stderr runs to over 250kB and 
commences thus:
desktop/netsurf.c netsurf\_init 68: version 'Test Build 
\(03 Mar 2005 22:35\)'
desktop/netsurf.c netsurf\_init 75: NetSurf on 
<riscos>, node <poolejpn.silver.ocn.ne.jp>, release 
<3.60>, version <2.02>, machine <arm-acorn>
rufl\_init.c rufl\_init 102: old font manager
rufl\_init.c rufl\_init 111: 508 faces, 99 families
rufl\_init.c rufl\_load\_cache 894: 
"AmTypeWrit.Medium2.Italic" not in font list
rufl\_init.c rufl\_load\_cache 894: "ANSI" not in font 
list
rufl\_init.c rufl\_load\_cache 894: "ANSI.Oblique" not in 
font list
rufl\_init.c rufl\_load\_cache 894: "gothic013.r48" not 
in font list
rufl\_init.c rufl\_load\_cache 894: "gothic013.r49" not 
in font list
rufl\_init.c rufl\_load\_cache 894: "gothic013.r4a" not 
in font list
rufl\_init.c rufl\_load\_cache 894: "gothic013.r4b" not 
in font list

etc etc until it gets to:
rufl\_init.c rufl\_init 127: scanning 505 
"Warsaw.UltraBold"
rufl\_init.c rufl\_init 127: scanning 506 
"Warsaw.UltraBold.Italic"
rufl\_init.c rufl\_init 127: scanning 507 "WIMPSymbol"
rufl\_init.c rufl\_init 154: 334 new charsets
rufl\_init.c rufl\_save\_cache 721: fwrite: 0x2: No such 
file or directory
riscos/gui.c ro\_gui\_check\_resolvers 422: 
Inet$Resolvers '203.139.161.40 203.139.160.74 '

the last part of which looks similar to the July 2004 
version's file.

There's also a lot of what looks like logs of Web page 
accesses, what's presumably taking up all the time is 
checking and scanning fonts \(I've got the Nuffield 
Risc OS port of the Wadalab Japanese fonts on board, 
so there are rather a lot of them\).

I've attempted to upload the stderr file for the 03 
Mar 2005 version.

At the moment, the slow loading means that the latest 
version of Netsurf is hard to use on my original-spec 
RPC700 \(RO 3.60\), so I'll stick with the earlier one 
for now.

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=453739

This log indicates that NetSurf failed to save the cache of font 
character data, which means that it has to rescan all your fonts 
each time it runs. 

The cache should be saved to <Wimp$ScrapDir>.RUfl\_cache. 
Does this machine have a Scrap directory and is it writeable? 

Thanks\! 
James
posts.author: bursa
posts.subject: #75 Slow to Load

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=453739

Fixed by 2005-04-05 changes to RUfl. A broken font was 
causing the charset->size field to be uninitialized, resulting in 
writing the cache failing.

When using a POST form with a TEXTAREA in it, if there is a linefeed in the HTML source following the TEXTAREA tag, a linefeed is inlcluded as the first character in the text area. I am not sure if this is strictly a bug, but no other browser I have tried does this. 

Also, when submitting the form, every line in the text area has a space character appended to it \(ie space inserted before linefeed characters\).
tickets.summary: linefeeds after textarea opening tag included in text area

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=906191

The second of these should now be fixed.
posts.author: jmb202
posts.subject: #86 linefeeds after textarea opening tag included in text area

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=906191

I'm unconvinced about the first one. I can see why other browsers do strip the leading CR/LF/CRLF sequence - in fact the example in the HTML spec appears to indicate that this is exactly what should happen. It does, however, seem to me to be a bit incongruous arbitrarily stripping some linebreaks whilst retaining others. Until I've read up more on the issue, I'm going to let the current behaviour  stand.
Whilst we're dealing with linebreaks, NetSurf fails to differentiate between CR, LF and CRLF sequences in text areas - they all get submitted as CRLF sequences. I believe this behaviour to be wrong.

scanning fonts \(which is only required once\). This can take 
several minutes if large Unicode fonts are installed \(for example 
Cyberbit\).

for the percentage to increase. Otherwise please email me 
your \!NetSurf.stderr after alt-break.

tickets.description:
Sometimes JPEGs render in false colours \(negative??\).  This is repeatable but variable, ie load a page \(from the web or from file\) containing a dozen or so JPEGs, and it is likely to affect some or all of them.  Reload the file, and it is likely to affect different images.  

This effect was not present in 25 April build, is present in 23 Jun & 25 Jun builds. I have tried and found it on four different sites.

john@jaharrison.me.uk

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=999199

This is due to a bug in Tinct for images that are internally 
compressed and use the optimisation for lack of alpha 
channel. The required fix is present in version 0.13 of Tinct, 
and will be made available following further testing.

posts.text:
Logged In: YES

12:02:19.06 \[Appl\NetSurf\] RMEnsure Iconv 0.04 Error 16\_10F iconv support requires the Iconv module 0.04 or newer

12:02:19.16 \[Appl\NetSurf\] RMEnsure Iconv 0.04 RMload System:Modules.Iconv
12:02:19.16 \[Appl\NetSurf\] RMEnsure Iconv 0.04 Error 16\_10F iconv support requires the Iconv module 0.04 or newer

etc etc\!

It would seem sensible to issue them once, rather than from within each WimpPollIdle loop\!?

Martin

netsurf@avisoft.f9.co.uk

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=906191

This is the result of how UnixLib's iconv support is implemented. As the module may be killed from underneath an application that uses it, UnixLib takes the sensible approach of attempting to load the module each time a conversion descriptor is opened.

As much of the text in NetSurf is passed through iconv before display, iconv\_open was being called a great deal. However, this isn't particularly efficient, as a great deal of conversions are between the same character sets. NetSurf has now been modified to cache the previous iconv conversion descriptor. This should fix the issue you are seeing \(with the side effect that conversion is up to 18 times faster\).
posts.author: jmb202
posts.subject: #98 Excessive RMEnsure Iconv

Reclosing this bug as the general case of path variables in links works correctly.
There's a bug in your new testcase in that it sets test$path to a non-path string \(and therefore won't work with anything\).
As for the hard space issue, this is a generic issue with fetching local files and I'll open a bug for that. The workaround is to replace the hard-space with %a0 in the URL.
The other issue \(of running an application whose \!Run file is typed to HTML\) is so unlikely to occur in the real world that I'm not inclined to fix it. If you wish to bundle HTML files in an application such that the file is opened in a browser when run, I advise doing what NetSurf's full save functionality does and make the \!Run file an obey file containing the single line "Filer\_Run <Obey$Dir>.foo/html"

tickets.description:
There are some problems with certain webpages that are utf8 encoded: e.g. <http://www.instituteus.com/news/turkish/>

Multibyte utf8 sequences such as e.g. \xC4 \xB0 and
\xE2 \x80 \x99 are not displayed correctly.

I checked the utf8 codes with Zap \(1.47\) and they are correct.

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=906191

Yes. This is a known issue with the parser. Essentially, if it detects a top-bit-set byte before the character set for the document is determined, it assumes 8859-1 and refuses to change this even if there's a <meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=foo"> tag later in the document.

See http://moose.mine.nu/testcases/utf8test.html for a testcase for this \(the source also contains comments explaining the issue in more depth and a pointer to the code section that causes this\).

I'm not entirely sure of the best solution to this \(other than perhaps parsing the <head> of the document first, extracting any charset information and then reparsing the whole document with the charset specified\).
posts.author: jmb202
posts.subject: #129 problems with charset=utf-8

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1055477


Why do almost all applications assume 8859-1 instead of using the current alphabet? It just doesn't make any sense.

tickets.description:
Fetching of file:/ URLs fails to convert the path to the current system local encoding. This generates an inconsistency in the way in which local files are identified.
In the case of a link in a web page, the URL will be UTF-8 encoded.
In the case of a file loaded from disc \(or from an URL/URI/IEURL file\), the URL will be encoded in the system local encoding.
When fetching the URL, the encoding is ignored \(as it's assumed to be correct\).
If the file path contains top-bit-set characters \(such as a hard-space\), the UTF-8 encoded link from an HTML document will fail to fetch the file as it'll look for ...%c2%a0... instead of whatever the representation of hard-space actually is on the system at the time.
To fix this requires a couple of steps:

1\) Make the fetching system assume that the URL is UTF-8 encoded \(which is already the case in 99% of cases\) and, in the case of file:/ URLs, convert the path to the system local encoding before the fetch occurs.

2\) When loading a local file \(or a reference to a local file\), convert the URL to UTF-8 encoding.
tickets.summary: Fetching of file:/ URLs ignores encoding

tickets.description:
When loading a page from a local storage medium \(i.e. as a file\) Netsurf fetches it from cache if it can rather than from the disc. This is very inconvenient for testing pages because you have to do a refresh after loading the page. Even then images are not always reloaded.

As there's no advantage in cacheing file objects it shouldn't be done.

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1432144

Further to this, if you follow a link which is broken because the file doesn't exist or was misnamed, and you then create the file and double-click on it, NetSurf still thinks the page doesn't exist. If you actually present a file to NS by dragging it onto the icon or into the window or explicitly typing in the path, then NS should open that file.
posts.author: minijem
posts.subject: #148 Loading local files from cache

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=906191

All of this should now be fixed; NetSurf now takes account of the last modification time of an object - if it's newer than NetSurf's cached version, the content gets re-fetched.
posts.author: jmb202
posts.subject: #148 Loading local files from cache

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1432144

I'm not sure about the fix. If I've tried a modification and don't like it I can restore the old file and it will then be older that the cached version. I still want to see the page or image I've asked for and not a newer one that I've discarded. Therefore I repeat that objects on the local hard disc \(or file server\) must be loaded from disc and not from cache regardless of modification date.
posts.author: minijem
posts.subject: #148 Loading local files from cache

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=906191

Not caching local files would mean that every time you
fetched a new page, all of NetSurf's local CSS files would
be reloaded. This is hardly efficient. Additionally, if
you're copying files around, it's hardly onerous to stamp
the file so the datestamp is updated. I suppose we could
fake HTTP ETag headers for local files; this would avoid the
need for restamping.
posts.author: jmb202
posts.subject: #148 Loading local files from cache

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1432144

That's a possibility but then the unchanged file would get uploaded to the web server - hardly efficient if you're using a dial-up line. Where are the local CSS files?
posts.author: minijem
posts.subject: #148 Loading local files from cache

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=906191

How would the unchanged file get uploaded to the web server?

Perhaps I had better explain exactly what NetSurf's caching
behaviour does.

When attempting to re-fetch an URL, NetSurf first determines
whether there's any cached copy and, if so, whether it's
still fresh \(i.e. if the age of the cached copy is younger
than some limit determined by the HTTP headers the server
sent when originally fetching the object\). If there is one,
that is used. If there is no cached copy, then the URL is
refetched.

If, however, there is a cached copy but it appears stale,
the cached content is revalidated. This will always happen
for local objects as the age limit is always 0. In general,
revalidation attempts to take account of two things:

1\) If the object has been modified since it was last fetched
\(by consulting the modification time of the object\)
2\) If the object's content has changed but not the
modification date.

If it detects that the object has been changed since it was
cached, then the object is refetched. Otherwise, the cached
copy is used. In this way, we can ensure that the viewed
content is up-to-date.

In the case of local files, the second test is not currently
used \(and my suggestion of faking the HTTP ETag header for
local files will fix this\).

The local CSS files can be found in \!NetSurf.Resources.
posts.author: jmb202
posts.subject: #148 Loading local files from cache

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1432144

OK, I use SiteMatch which uploads changed files to the web sites - one of a few such programs. I can exclude files from the upload but it's a fiddle.
Thanks for the explanation. I looked in \!NetSurf.Resources and didn't notice the two CSS files. I agree you don't want to load them every time if they're in RAM, though it's only 14k. If there was a "flush cache" option on the icon bar menu \(or even on Choices/cache\) that would alleviate the problem and the date/time check would be fine.
posts.author: minijem
posts.subject: #148 Loading local files from cache

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=906191

I don't understand why you think NetSurf's caching behaviour
hinders your usage of SiteMatch; once I've implemented the
ETag header faking for local files, it'll do everything you
wanted \(and avoid the issues related with not caching local
objects at all\). It also removes the need for any "flush
cache" buttons.

As for the CSS files, they may be "only 14k" but without
caching, that's 14k for every HTML document you have open at
any one time. That also takes no account of the processing
time needed to parse the CSS files and apply the rules
contained within them to the HTML documents.

Often I have noticed that the percentage received of a file \(as reported in NetSurf's status bar\) exceeds 100%, at which point the value becomes meaningless. This is presumably because the original estimation of the file size was incorrect; e.g. "Received 21.87 kB of 40.00 B \(55982%\)".

tickets.description:
NetSurf \(recent builds, including 08 Feb 2006 0045\)
fails to find fonts stored by EasyFontPro and so does
not offer them in its menu.
Deleting rufl\_cache and trying again results in NetSurf
silently dying \(example log from such an event attached\).

EasyFontPro adds its fonts to Font$Path by the macro
<EasyFSPro$Fonts> which points to
<EasyFSPro$Dir>.Fabis0004.^.
There is no such Fabis0004 directory present and the
resulting <EasyFSPro$Dir>. contains a 0 subdirectory
followed by various numbered subdirectories. Presumably
normally EasyFontPro does some 'magic' when the
FontManager normally investigates the path. 

Additionally, EasyFontPro turns all the files within
the original font directories into numbered files
within numbered subdirectories \(presumably to more
efficiently store them\) along with some internal record
of what is what. 

I wonder if either or both of these factors are
tripping up the 'check for Outlines data' changes to
RUfl since a\) the path doesn't really exist b\) the
structure inside is not that of normal fonts.
EasyFontPro may fool the Font Manager but cannot fool
the Filer, perhaps?
tickets.summary: NetSurf fails to find fonts in EasyFontPro

tickets.description:
Any html markup in the value of a textarea field is 
not being displayed. It is essential that markup is 
treated as plain text since the form may be used to 
edit that markup.

For example you might put a link to a picture in a 
bulletin board post, or add a streetmap link to a 
database entry for an event.

This could also apply to special characters lile the 
ampersand and pound sign, but other browsers tend to 
convert these.

Btw, when I try to submit this using NetSurf I get a 
parsing error.

minijem

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1131038

This will be fixed as soon as I get my SVN access.

However, the text you get out won't always be the same as the text that's in the page source.

This is because of some idiosyncracies in the HTML4 and XML specs which mean that textarea contents are parsed for HTML tags. So according to the spec, if a server wants a client to display tags as text, it should replace the appropriate characters with html entities.

Once the page has been parsed into the XML tree we have no way of directly accessing the source text, so can't display the unprocessed form. We could probably rework the parsing to support this, but it would probably require a fair amount of work. The only time I can think of when you'd have raw HTML tags in a textarea is when you're editing something that contains HTML tags, so the text->XML->text conversion process shouldn't cause any serious problems.

posts.subject: #176 Markup in textarea value

tickets.description: NS 28th Feb. - When I removed the start of a comment but left the start of tag and the end comment i.e. <\!--July:--> changed to <July:--> text further down in a different table cell disappeared. There were no other intervening comment delimiters or any preceding open comment. Removing the -- caused the text to reappear, as did removing both delimiters completely. Unless a comment is currently open the --> should be ignored except that the > may terminate an open tag. If the tag is not recognised then the whole thing should be regarded as displayable.

served with "Content-Type: image/png".

type from the content for images in future.

tickets.description:
If an anchor tag occurs in the middle of a 'word' then the word can be split at that point across two lines.

Specifically, a sequence such as
\(<a href="images/dart.jpeg" target="\_new">photo - 53 kbytes</a>\)
can leave the open bracket at the end of a line despit e the fact that there is no white space between it and "photo". Changing the window size can leave the closing bracket by itself on the next line.

This comes from http://www.minimarcos.org.uk/mmhdt.html

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1432144

This is still a problem. i suspect it can happen with any tag or a comment in the middle of a word.

tickets.description:
Netsurf will not allow you to paste text from the clipboard into a form text field or text area unless it has been cut or copied from a text file. If the text is copied from an html file, either from a browser window or from the file opened in \!Edit, it will be treated as a new page, wiping out the form. This happens whether the fragment makes any sense as a web page or not.

The workaround is to open an \!Edit window, type in some random text to make it a text file, paste in the copied text, delete the random text and then save the file into the form and then close the \!Edit window discarding the contents - very messy\! You could probably cut and paste from the text file too.

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1432144

It looks like this has been fixed\!

Thanks.

posts.subject: #217 Can't paste text into form

posts.author: jtytgat
posts.subject: #222 Window iconize no longer works for osnews.com

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=893271

This does appear to be an OS bug.  I have reproduced it with
\!Edit.  Here's how:

1\. Create a new Edit window.  Save it as "iiiiiiiiiiiiiii"
2\. Create another.  Save it as "mmmmmmmmmmmmmmm"
3\. Iconise both windows.

The "m" one won't appear.  I suspect this has something to
do with the Pinboard truncating at a number of characters,
rather than a number of pixels.  This would also explain why
it works just fine at different point sizes and different
fonts, and why some sites work and others do not.

Given this isn't a bug in NetSurf, I have reduced its
priority to the lowest, incase Adrian can thing of some
cunning work around.  We might want to experiment to see
precisely how many pixels, etc, causes it to fail, and make
sure we truncate it for the Pinboard instead.

posts.subject: #222 Window iconize no longer works for osnews.com

need to let this remain open.

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1432144

I think this is the same bug that I reported earlier. If you cut and paste from an html file or URI/URL, or drag and drop the file then Netsurf treats it as a new page and runs it. If the source was a text file then it goes into the form field as intended. The workaround is to set the file type to text, or to paste the URL into a text file in \!Edit and then copy it out again, but note that a new \!Edit window won't work unless you type some text first to establish the file type.

Netsurf has to distinguish between dropping html into a form field, and dropping it elsewhere in a browser window.

tickets.description:
At present with a proxy set, NetSurf passes requests
straight to it. If I attempt to access
http://localhost, for example, my local proxy will try
to talk to itself.
Since we have a friendly user interface for configuring
the connection again, it would be useful to be able to
exclude certain URLs/requests from being passed on to
the proxy. At least it is easy enough to turn the
proxying on and off again now without having to quit
NetSurf and edit the Choices and restart.

I would suggest that passing localhost through is never
likely to be useful behaviour.
tickets.summary: NetSurf sends requests (e.g. localhost) to proxies blindly

tickets.description:
I may have mis-understood the new fetcher but, as a webmaster, I am a
little concerned about the default value of max\_fetchers\_per\_host; For
keepalive connections the RFC \(8.1.4 Practical Considerations\) states

Clients that use persistent connections SHOULD limit the number of
simultaneous connections that they maintain to a given server. A 
single user client SHOULD NOT maintain more than 2 connections
with any server or proxy.

which suggests that max\_fetchers\_per\_host should be set to 2 rather
than 5.

John

john.p.baker@bristol.ac.uk

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=453739

Fixed in r2854.
posts.author: bursa
posts.subject: #236 max_fetchers_per_host

tickets.description:
Every time I use the Export as text \(Ctrl-F3\) option,
any hard spaces in the source become A-circumflex
characters in the plain text output.



On the IMDb site, for example, the 'menu bar' at the
bottom comes out as:



HomeÂ | SearchÂ | Now PlayingÂ | NewsÂ | My MoviesÂ |
GamesÂ | BoardsÂ | HelpÂ | USÂ MovieÂ ShowtimesÂ |
TopÂ 250Â | RegisterÂ | Recommendations



\(don't know how well that will work when pasted in the
Web form - sorry\)

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=453739

The text is exported as UTF-8 Unicode, in which a hard space
will be encoded in two bytes \(A-circumflex, space\).

We could have an option to export as Latin-1 if possible.
posts.author: bursa
posts.subject: #248 nbsp becomes Acirc

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=208570

Latin-1 sounds good;  it would be more generally useful
under RISC OS.  \(I'd noticed that accented characters came
out as multi-byte encodings, but hadn't thought to connect
this to the hard space behaviour for some reason.\)

tickets.description:
When using Netsurf to view web pages that may have 
content accessable via https:// \(e.g. www.drobe.co.uk 
has a Paypal donate button\) and a simple proxy server 
is configured, Netsurf will exit and leave the 
hourglass running.

Any use of https:// with a proxy will cause Netsurf to 
exit without error. The log file registers a SSL 
connection made to the proxy and nothing else - no 
subsequent errors or warnings are reported.

Configuring no proxy solves the problem, even if the 
proxy performs transparent proxying. The proxy server 
is squid-2.5 STABLE 1-2 running on Red Hat Linux 9.0.

Netsurf 07-May-2006 build running on 233 MHz rev S 
StrongARM Risc PC with 64 MB RAM, 2MB VRAM, 
WindowManager 3.98 and RISC OS 3.70.

Ok, so it's managing to exit abnormally and yet bypass all our checks. Can you try the following, please?:

1\) Fetch Reporter from http://www.avisoft.f9.co.uk/Reporter.htm
2\) Fetch http://moose.mine.nu/ns-signal-debug.zip
3\) Run Reporter and turn on VDU4 logging \(menu->Vdu4On\)
4\) Run the build of NS that you downloaded in step 2 and make it crash
5\) Save the log that Reporter makes \(menu->Save\) - By default, this saves to RAM::$.ReportList, so either ensure you have a RAM disc created or change the save location in Reporter's choices.
6\) Append the log file produced to this bug.

Thanks.

tickets.description:
The makefile depends on the source directory name being
"netsurf". I noticed this while preparing to build a
.deb for nsgtk from an exported tree \(rev. 2601\). I've
renamed my checked-out tree "netsurf.svn" :-\)

The attached patch hacks around this somewhat, and a
little less than ideally \*but\* less intrusively; it
should really remove all "netsurf/" from all \#includes.

It hard-links some files into place for access by
nsgtk, and I've altered the clean target appropriately.

I've removed \*most\* hard-coding of /usr/bin/gcc.

I've left in -I.. in $\(CFLAGS\_RISCOS\), but I think that
this really needs to be removed too.

NOTE: It /may/ break building of the other versions
\(I've not checked this\).

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=453739

Thanks for the patch\! I'll have a look in detail when I have
more time.

tickets.description:
Since I started experimenting with different desktop themes \(e.g. http://jymbob.drobe.co.uk\) I have become more aware of which icons have their own palette, because they do not blend in with their surroundings like those that use the desktop palette.

The toolbar icons in the default Netsurf theme 'Aletheia' seem to fall into this category; I'm currently using a green-tinged desktop palette but the toolbar icons remain resolutely light grey. I think it would make more sense for them to use the desktop palette.
tickets.summary: Aletheia: toolbar icons don't use desktop palette

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=453739

I think the icons are 256 colours, so as far as I know this
isn't possible.
posts.author: bursa
posts.subject: #255 Aletheia: toolbar icons don't use desktop palette

posts.author: bursa
posts.subject: #255 Aletheia: toolbar icons don't use desktop palette

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1227467

Well it's hard to tell given the way that the themes are packaged up, but I can reduce a screen snapshot of the 'Aletheia' toolbar to 8 grey levels \(in InterGif\) without any visible deterioration. Is there any reason why these \(simple, monochrome\) sprites should use 8 bits per pixel?
posts.author: mittens
posts.subject: #255 Aletheia: toolbar icons don't use desktop palette

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=826159

The sprites have a subtle fade from a light grey to a darker gray on the face of the icons. More shades of grey also improve the border anti-aliasing. 

Please tell me what format the sprites need to be for the desktop palette thing to work. \(The icons are currently 256 colour sprites with no palette.\)
posts.author: tlsa
posts.subject: #255 Aletheia: toolbar icons don't use desktop palette

posts.text:
Logged In: NO 

As far as I know, only 16 colour sprites with no palette of their own are rendered using the desktop palette. Experimentation appears to confirm this.

The border anti-aliasing doesn't work \(in fact it is unsightly\) with any window background tile of a significantly different colour than light grey. The background of NetSurf's tool bar does not seem to be under control of the theme; it is the same as in all other windows. 

It is for this reason that I don't generally like grey anti-aliasing around the borders of icons - if nothing else then they will look odd against a coloured Pinboard backdrop. The gradated sprite masks provided by RISC OS Select may be some help with this in future.
posts.author: nobody
posts.subject: #255 Aletheia: toolbar icons don't use desktop palette

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=826159

I have attached a zip file containing a 16 colour version of Aletheia. Please copy it into Choices:WWW.NetSurf.Themes and select the Aletheia16 theme from NetSurf's theme config window. The Throbber has not been converted, only the buttons as it would be a lot more work. I don't intend to update the theme again until I overhaul it for version 1.0.
posts.author: tlsa
posts.subject: #255 Aletheia: toolbar icons don't use desktop palette

posts.author: tlsa
posts.subject: #255 Aletheia: toolbar icons don't use desktop palette

posts.author: tlsa
posts.subject: #255 Aletheia: toolbar icons don't use desktop palette

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1227467

IMO the 16 colour version of Aletheia does look better \(than the original\) with an alternative desktop palette and window tile sprite - see attached screenshot. 

Note the light green fringe on the faded icon. This is becase the window tile sprite isn't a uniform colour and doesn't quite match colour 1 in the Wimp palette. Arguably this is the fault of the desktop theme and not NetSurf, but it could be avoided by using semi-transparent pixels to anti-alias the icon edges.

tickets.description:

Global History Today directory, with the current datestamp. 
When the retention  period for the disc cache has elapsed, the 
entries are deleted, but  immediately copied, from the Hotlist, 
back into Today again.

I first noticed this problem with Test Build \(16 Apr 2006 10:45\)
\[Test Build \(06 Apr 2006 18:00\) was not affected\]

Tony

old\_coaster@yahoo.co.uk
tickets.summary: hotlist wrongly copied to global history

posts.author: bursa
posts.subject: #259 hotlist wrongly copied to global history

posts.author: jmb202
posts.subject: #259 hotlist wrongly copied to global history

tickets.description:
Netsurf Test Build: 24 May 2006 23:00
Kinetic RPC, RO 4.39
RAM 88Mb free at start

The above version \(and recent previous versions - sorry can't be specific\) open up multiple DA in the Task Window.

e.g. www.drobe.co.uk opens a DA of 328k
www.streetmap.co.uk opens a DA of 616k

These are in addition to the main Netsurf DA which seems to grow without releasing much of its memory until an out of memory error appears on screen. When I get this error and check the Task Window I have found as many as 8 Netsurf dynamic areas of varying size.
Memory is released by quiting the app.

This doesn't appear to be related to opening multiple windows. It happens with some websites and not others whether in an original window or not.

Regards
Gary Jones \(gary.athome AT ntlworld DOT com\)

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=453739

The additional DAs are used for large objects \(such as
images\), and should disappear eventually when the objects
are freed.
posts.author: bursa
posts.subject: #260 DA memory not released

tickets.description:
When sites are added to the hotlist, they add sucessfully; however, if I then move these sites into another directory in the hotlist, this sorting is not preserved when NetSurf is quitted and re-loaded.

pnyoung@ormail.co.uk

RISC OS 5.11
24 May 2006 build.

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=906191

I am unable to reproduce this. Does it still happen with the
latest build? If so, can you provide exact instructions on
how to reproduce it please.
posts.author: jmb202
posts.subject: #261 Sort failure in hotlist.

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1386864

Sorry for the slow response; just got back from holiday yesterday.

Yes, it still happens with the latest build, and that then produces the bbc site cookies problem mentioned elsewhere on this tracker, so I've reverted to the older version till cookies are sorted.

I'm afraid that the exact instructions as to how to reproduce it are more or less as in my posting\! :-\)

1\) Add a site to the hotlist.

2\) Sort this site to an appropriate place in a directory in the hotlist.

3\) The next time NS is run, the site is now back where it was originally put before the sort.

Best wishes,

Peter.
posts.author: pnyoung
posts.subject: #261 Sort failure in hotlist.

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=906191

Can you try moving your hotlist file \(Choices:WWW.NetSurf.Hotlist\) away, starting NetSurf and then try adding/moving entries to the default hotlist. I'm completely unable to reproduce this which suggests that there's something strange with your hotlist file. Also, how are you adding sites to your hotlist?
posts.author: jmb202
posts.subject: #261 Sort failure in hotlist.

posts.text:
Logged In: YES

I'm completely unable to reproduce this which suggests that there's something strange with your hotlist file. Also, how are you adding sites to your hotlist?
posts.author: jmb202
posts.subject: #261 Sort failure in hotlist.

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1386864

Thanks for this help.

I tried moving out and reconstructing the hotlist, and it only worked up to a point. The first directory I constructed saved OK, and was still as I left it when I re-ran NS. However, I then made another directory, and saved three more sites into it; this then didn't reappear as it was sorted on re-running.

Obviously I have something malformed somewhere, but I wonder what?

I'm now back to my original partly-unsorted hotlist.

Best wishes,

Peter.

posts.subject: #261 Sort failure in hotlist.

Peter.

Cheers.

tickets.description:
I noticed this some time ago. Checking the date for the other themes, I guess 11th of March this year. Anyway... If I go to the theme site for NetSurf and click on the RO5 theme from Richard Hallas, it starts downloading. When it has downloaded, and I press the install button, I get a 'Warning from NetSurf' \(shouldn't that be an error?\): "An error occurred whilst trying to install the downloaded theme.". Obviously, the theme is not installed.

Playing around a bit, if I shift-click the "Install theme..." link, save the file, put it in Choices:WWW.NetSurf.Themes, I can choose it and run it, with no apparant problems.

The other themes seem OK.

posts.text:
Logged In: NO 

Could the problem relate to the fact that this is the only theme with spaces in its name? As the theme designer, I can confirm that the theme does work fine if installed manually, and I'm pretty sure that the installation problem is a new one \(i.e. I think I tried the auto-installation successfully in a previous version of NetSurf\). The only difference between this theme and the IYONIX one is the design of the animated activity icon, and yet the IYONIX theme installs without problems.
posts.author: nobody
posts.subject: #263 Cannot load the RO5 theme

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=999199

This has now been fixed.
posts.author: not_ginger_matt
posts.subject: #263 Cannot load the RO5 theme

tickets.description:
There is an anomaly with autoscrolling whilst dragging a URL within the hotlist or global history. Scrolling upwards does not attain the same speed as downwards until the pointer is moved over the tool bar at the top of the window. This seems to be at odds with the extent of the vertical scrollbar and scrollable area, both of which stop short of the top of the window. 

Actually, even if the scrollbar reached the top of the window I still think that the autoscroll borders should reflect the visible work area \(i.e. excluding any internal toolbars\). 

Using NetSurf test build 28 May 2006 17:00 on an A9Home with RISC OS 4.42.

http://svn.gna.org/viewcvs/wesnoth/tags/1.1.4/changelog?rev=11738&view=markup kills Netsurf \(build 24/05/2006 11:00\)

\(BTW, failure to wordwrpa long lines in web forms can be a pain too - I hope I typed that URL right.

Just in case, above link accessible from main page at http://www.wesnoth.org

I speculate that dodgy CSS is the cause.

Can't attach a logfile. My hard disk name has a space in it, and I get asked to please insert disk 114&Acirc;Gb. This causes me to lose the contents of the web form too. See http://www.simon-smith.org/log.zip instead

Will update to latest Netsurf version and post again if behaviour changes.

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1173218

Tried to post log file from RAM disc.
Also, latest version of Ns still crashed, but the log file generated is slightly different, so I have updated the zip with both versions.

posts.subject: #266 Subversion changelog link kills Netsurf

tickets.description:
Example URL:
http://66.249.93.104/search?q=cache:TEtBUWTQW9UJ:www.opsi.gov.uk/si/si2006/uksi\_20061623\_en.pdf+South+Coast+Ambulance+Trust&hl=en&gl=uk&ct=clnk&cd=3&ie=UTF-8
\(or searching google for 'Random pdf' and using 'View as HTML'\)

It appears that the advent of absolute positioning has broken the appearance of PDFs converted to HTML by Google. The text from the PDF file ends up all on one line overprinting itself.

\(06 Jul 2006 06:45 version\) I have gone back over previous versions and definitely all since 26 Jun 2006 05:00 have exhibited this problem though 24 Jun 2006 18:00 displays them OK.

The format of the HTML generated seems odd anyway.
<meta http-equiv ...>
<table>... // ...</table>
<html><head><meta stuff \(Acrobat Distiller output from here onwards\)</head><body> ...loads of <div style="position:absolute";...>...</div></body></html>

but ultimately it seems to be that NetSurf is not doing anything with the 
"top:foo" so ends up with everything printed as though it were attached to the top of the window.
tickets.summary: Google's 'View as HTML' for PDF broken since abs positioning

posts.text: Minimal case for mishandling top:foo in position:absolute

James

tickets.description:
I would like to be able to use the latest builds of NetSurf to access my Google mail account. This is a popular web-based e-mail service which has an optional 'plain HTML' interface which is ideally suited to NetSurf if one can overcome the obstacle of logging in.

I am currently unable to log in to my account using test build 13 Jul 2006 23:00. The sequence of events is as follows:

I enter the URL http://mail.google.com in one of NetSurf's URL input fields. This redirects momentarily to http://mail.google.com/mail/ and then to a  log-in page with the following URL:

https://www.google.com/accounts/ServiceLogin?service=mail&passive=true&rm=false&continue=http%3A%2F%2Fmail.google.com%2Fmail%2F%3Fui%3Dhtml%26zy%3Dl&ltmpl=googlemail&ltmplcache=2

Entering my user name and password takes me momentarily to:

https://www.google.com/accounts/CheckCookie?continue=http%3A%2F%2Fmail.google.com%2Fmail%2F%3Fui%3Dhtml%26zy%3Dl&service=mail&chtml=LoginDoneHtml

Which redirects to the following \(broken-looking\) URL:

https://www.google.com/accounts/'http://mail.google.com/mail/?ui=html&zy=l'

This page displays the error message 'The page you requested is invalid'. It does not seem to make a difference whether or not I enabled the 'Remember me on this computer' option on the log-in page.

However I can, with some difficulty, access Google mail using a test build dating from 24 Feb 2006 20:45 \(which I keep specifically for this purpose\).

Initially, logging in leads me to a broken URL with the same error message \("The page you requested is invalid"\) as the latest test build:

https://www.google.com/accounts/'http://mail.google.com/mail/?ui=html&zy=l&auth=QDNNNTjNNNO1b7CM8KBVM1n-WosjpSCloMhd\_UKvPFPWfNLh1sPJFisleINaJ23NZvYu1gh6uADugnGx0uncCuZiatEPCpoVVOjCKxwPTXNf\_OR6pdQCJXxpwqkkV\_\_O-AeiFy2iJY4Ag4VUf7dNQUvuK-hNY6f5'

\(I have scrambled the final part of this URL - after "&auth=" - to
avoid compromising my account's security.\)

Despite the error message, returning to http://mail.google.com/mail/ allows me to access my account \(with the February test build\). Instead of the usual invitation to log-in, a page is displayed giving the options of a JavaScript interface \('standard view'\), a non-JS interface \('basic HTML view'\) and a version for mobile phones. Selecting 'basic HTML view' displays my e-mail inbox correctly.

The URL for the interface selection page resembles the following \(again, I have scrambled the 'auth' code\):

http://mail.google.com/mail/?auth=DQANNTfNNNNwzbBGpxjzAAajcdR7W76cqTv5rOCX9-FfMi0M0g-5HCT4l6wV4rz-leCnndzDzGIC8F\_N9nejkUt2bvuqYXAbDuFrQMNEJIUGsJngNv9d89A6FZ6EXDtOzXWSm-3TVgRcuD510Yobe6jTuLixcr0n&mk=emy0j78zctf6

With the old version of NetSurf, even an apparently unsucessful log-in
generates several additional Google cookies \(whether or not I tick 'Remember me on this computer'\). It is presumably one \(or more\) of these which enables access to my account.

I believe the problem relates to cookie handling, but the recent improvements in this area do not seem to have resolved it. It was obviously the  intention of the site's designers that it should work with non-JavaScript browsers, so I am hopeful that NetSurf can do it.

Many thanks for your time.

posts.author: simon_smith
posts.subject: #299 'Abort download window' won't close on 'No'

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=999199

NetSurfs internal window handling wan't correctly releasing handles for closed browser windows, so if this window handle was later re-used it would be passed onto the browser window icon handling code \(ie none\) and the query/download windows wouldn't respond.

tickets.description: There are all sorts of problems associated with cutting, copying and pasting text in text areas on forms. Cut and copy don't work. Paste does work, but if an area of text has been selected then spurious bits of the pasted text can also appear in reverse video. Ctrl-Z doesn't clear the selected text. Ctrl-U does clear the selection but doesn't reset the text area.

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1131038

\- cut, copy and ctrl-z work for me. However cut only seems to work if the caret is in the text box
\- text selection processing/rendering is fairly buggy at the moment, this will hopefully be fixed soon :\)
\- ctrl-u should delete the current line of text
posts.author: phlamethrower
posts.subject: #306 Editing text in textarea

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1432144

Everything sems to hinge on point 2. However Ctrl-X appears to do nothing and Ctrl-Z may or may not work depending on circumstances. Ctrl-C does copy to the clipboard but only what you can succesfully select. This isn't necessarily what you drag over but may be one line below or somewhere else. Things get worse when you have more than one line. Ctrl-V pastes what's on the clipboard but one line above the cursor, and then adds an extra newline.
Repositioning the cursor can lead to random bits of text being highlighted - I'll upload a screen shot separately as SF gave me an error the first time and trashed everything I'd typed in. Clicking Adjust does not select the text between the cursor and the pointer.
Ctrl-U clears the current line but does not delete it.
posts.author: minijem
posts.subject: #306 Editing text in textarea

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1131038

Try the latest build, it's got a lot of fixes for textareas.

AFAIK the only remaining issues are:
\- text selection is still broken in various ways
\- ctrl-x possibly broken. It works fine for me on OS 5 and 3.7, providing the cursor is in the text area at the time. what OS are you using?
\- ctrl-z possibly broken. seems to work fine for me though.

You're right about the ctrl-u behaviour - it only clears the line, not delete it. That's how it was designed, so if you'd rather have it delete the line you could open a feature request for it. Once text selection is working properly I don't think there'll be much use for it.

I'll probably be looking at the text selection next, but fixing it could take some time :\(
posts.author: phlamethrower
posts.subject: #306 Editing text in textarea

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1432144

I'm trying the latest version now. Ctrl-X still not working \(doesn't remove the text and doesn't put it on the clipboard\). I'm using Adjust 1i2 \(4.39\).
I agree with you about Ctrl-U. It's only really any use if it clears the whole text area. Single lines can be done with select and cut. This situation is aggravated because Reset buttons don't work. I haven't raised a bug report for that one.
Ctrl-Z seems to be working with properly selected text \(right now dragging the pointer is selecting text on several consecutive lines and merging all the fragments into one line\). Bits of text that are highlighted spuriously don't get returned to normal. Sometimes dragging the pointer produces a text file icon like holding down Select over selected text, but without any text being selected.

tickets.description:
I'm using NS 6-Aug-2006, 18:00 build on VirtualRPC
Adjust running RO 4.39

Viewing the page
http://simple.wikipedia.org.wiki/Main\_Page, I set the
magnification to 150%. The view area \(the RO window\) is
smaller than the page size in both the horizontal and
vertical directions.

I wanted to scroll down the page, so grabbed a piece of
page background at the bottom of the visible page, to
the right of the left-hand grey margin.

I move the mouse upward, the pointer changed to a hand
shape and the page scrolled down. When the hand/pointer
got \*almost\* to the NS toolbar, the whole visible web
page started to oscillate up and down slightly \(though
sometimes it'll go left-right\) - usually as the tip of
the pointer reaches the toolbar.

It's not easy to reproduce but I have been able to do
so. It only seems to happen at 150% magnification, I've
not seen it happen at other scales.

I have been able to reproduce this effect on other
websites - such as http://news.bbc.co.uk/ or
http://iconbar.com/

I recently suggested an enhancement request 1537335 for
the Select-style "swipe" with the mouse pointer to
highlight text in writable icons as this wasn't working.

On further investigation, I've found that it's because
I swipe backwards from the right to the left and tend
to start in the blank area to the right of the text.

I'm not quite sure if this is a bug or not but here are

right to left by starting the swipe in the blank area

In NS writable icons, I can't do this \(and struggle to
reliably swipe leftward from the last character\).
Swiping left or right-ward within text works reliably.

Thanks,
James

tickets.description:
Visiting the frontpage of http://www.standaard.be/ means loading about 150 objects and most of them load very quickly.  However the last object takes a long time and during that period NetSurf memory usage grows steadily to about 22 MByte while communication with the server goes on.

I suspect this memory usage is unnecessary and might show a memory leak in the redirection code : in the attached log file you see that the last object to be loaded is njs.gif which constantly gets refered to another URL by a 303 Object Moved server responce, each time adding to the URL the "&dcsredirect=1" string.  This happens about 292 times and then its stops \(not sure why\).  But in the meanwhile I guess about 15 MByte of RAM is wasted.

So several questions:
\- Is NetSurf behaving correctly in the sense that the server constantly replies with 303 Object Moved ? I guess this is a server/website configuration stupidity, right ?
\- Shouldn't there be a sensible bound to the number of URL redirections ? Or is there one but not yet met ? Or is the 292 one ?
\- Probably the most important question : am I right suspecting there is a memory leak in the redirection code ?
tickets.summary: Memory leak when redirection is taken ?

tickets.description:
When attempting to render/display a local file of about 300k, Netsurf \(15 Aug build\) crashed - after some long time.

It reported that the document was complete \(though nothing was displayed\) after 8.5 seconds or so and then, almost immediately, the red/yellow hourglass appeared. After a further minute Netsurf closed the logfile after giving a trace and register dump.

Early on in the rendering process a warning indicated that box->last was wrong. The entire document seemed to have been rendered before a whole  lot of additional stuff was written to the log - apparently some configuration information and finally many lines relating to fonts and font names.

Unfortunately the log file is 17Mb raw \(about a third of a Mb as a zip file\) - which sourceforge complained about - incompletely - as an error.

I have a zip file containing the original local file and the log if you wish me to forward it direct to someone.

Keith Hopper
asgard@inspire.net.nz

PS Sorry that this is the third error report this am - but I have the odd feeling that this one might be related to the first one.

tickets.description:
\*\*Original Post to Mail list \[amended\] as follows since your response\*\* 

Since the upgrade of NetSurf \[around the end of May \(delete previous ref to Style Sheets\)\] 
I have been unable to complete any financial transactions via https web pages.

\[ Normal HTTPS usage for sign-up to mail lists, register with SourceForge etc.is perfect\! \]

This first showed with PayPal, which I was not too bothered about as I 
only rarely use it, and after the kerfuffle with their new T&C 
acknowlegement, I am even less so.

However, this week I needed to upgrade my details with ISP 
'Free-online.Net' \( branch of PlusNet\)
and find it impossible to log into the secure section. My last \[sucessful\] access 
was in January.

The open pages of this site load quickly and fully with no problems - 

\- I am on Dial-Up -

But as soon as I go to the secure pages everything slows to a crawl. 
Lots of errors occur such as 'errror loading object', 'SSL timedout' 
and 'failed after 30xxx millisec'

During all this Style sheets are loading and then the message 
'Converting xxx bytes' appears for what appears to be up to 40 odd 
seconds at a time.

Finally 'loading xx objects' takes for ever then 'processing page' 
starts.

A few seconds after this NetSurf disappears from the Icon bar with a 
continuous Hour Glass.

PayPal behaviour is similar.

Inspection of the Log shows 'Termination signal received: Broken pipe' 
as the final entry

Throughout the log there are many listings of the ISP's secure 
certificate.

\[ copy of log 'nslog/zip' attached - Ns version 0804\]

Tried again today with version 0819 and got a new error, never seen before,
a window saying 'netsurf failed to verify SSL certificate'
and listing three certificate names.

best regards - Bryn Evans

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=906191
Originator: NO

The broken pipe crash should be fixed now. SSL connections in general are slow, although I'm not sure there's much we can do about that. However, I've also reverted the change which prevented caching of SSL connection handles, so it may now be a bit faster.

The certificate verification dialog appearing is not an error; it's telling you that NetSurf couldn't verify the validity of the certificate chain provided by the server, so it's providing you with the details to make a decision as to whether you trust the other party or not.

Please test with the latest build \(18/01/2007 01:30 UTC\) and report back about whether you experience any further broken pipe crashes or SSL timeouts. For the timebeing, I'm going to reduce the priority of this bug as it's no longer a crash.
posts.author: jmb202
posts.subject: #327 Secure pages problems

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=906191
Originator: NO

Closing this as SSL connections are now back to the same kind of speed as they were before parallel fetching and handle caching was implemented.
posts.author: jmb202
posts.subject: #327 Secure pages problems

Test Build \(04 Feb 2007 13:00\)

Since last reporting, I have upgraded the RPC memory to 128MB and, after
running NetSurf the free memory is about 113MB.

Loading a full-saved page, containing many images, causes NetSurf to
claim a total of 69960K in nine DMA slots. At this point the hard drive
indicator light flashes continuously, at intervals of about a second.
When the page is closed, NetSurf does not release all the memory, but
still occupies 65920K in one DMA slot.

Re-loading the same page causes NetSurf to claim a total of 71084K in
eight DMA slots. Loading more pages eventually leads to

NetSurf: NetSurf is running out of memory.
Please free some memory and try again.

Disregarding this request, loading more files and/or directories causes
the Task Manager to show Next 0K, Free 0K. At that point

NetSurf: NetSurf is running out of memory.
Please free some memory and try again.

Filer:   There is not enough memory to load all of the available
sprites. This may affect the appearance of files and
applications.

Despite these errors, it is now possible to quit NetSurf \(or other
application\) and I have not been able to reproduce the circumstances,
described in my initial report, where alt-break was needed to regain
control \(because the task manager could not function\).

NetSurf memory handling seems to have improved, but there remain some
problems, particularly in the release of memory, when no longer needed.

Tony

tickets.description:
Since downloading the latest test build of NetSurf \(the first to support frames properly\) I have found that foreground images are often not fully redrawn. Large blank rectangles are left where the image should be.

Forcing this area of the page to be redrawn \(for example by dragging a window over it or scrolling up/down\) does not cure the problem. However reformatting the page \(e.g. by resizing the window\) usually does cure it.

I attach a screenshot showing this bug at the following URL:

http://www.imdb.com/gallery/ss/0285403/1SCRaeN04.jpg?path=pgallery&seq=15
System info:
Netsurf Test Build 02 Sep 2006 9:15
StrongARM Risc PC with 42 Mb RAM
RISC OS 4 'Adjust'.

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=999199

This looks very much like an iframe not being correctly 
positioned initially.
posts.author: not_ginger_matt
posts.subject: #336 Images not fully redrawn (blank rectangles)

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=999199

The iframe windows didn't have NO\_BOUNDS set, and thus 
were initially being forced inside the visible area of the 
parent. This has now been fixed and the page renders as 
expected.

posts.subject: #336 Images not fully redrawn (blank rectangles)

tickets.description: Changing to use the "system" font on the dektop causes Netsurf to complain of a bad font handle.
Bug item 1551183 has been fixed, but there is still a minor problem: changing the scale view doesn't work unless the page is reloaded.

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=999199

The issue here is that of an unclear GUI. Scaling the page via the toolbar results in the frameset page being scaled \(invisible to the user.\) When refreshing the child frames are then propogated with the scale of the parent and thus it appears to work.
Although the fix is relatively simple, I'm hesitant to introduce it until a new menu structure and supporting UI is introduced such that an established way of what actions affect which windows is done.
A further issue is whether we should scale the actual frame sizes or just the content. I'd probably suggest that the scale of the parent frameset is used for the frames \(rather than either the frame scale or nothing\) as it errs towards the side of how the page author expects the content to be layed out.
posts.author: not_ginger_matt
posts.subject: #338 Scale view and frames

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=999199

I've now updated the scale view dialog to make the operations clearer, and also made so that any scale changes are also applied to the dimensions and content of all child frames, both inline or frameset based. Similarly, Ctrl+resize will now correctly work for frame based pages.

tickets.description:
Hi, I'm using the current latest build - 07 Sep 2006, 09:45

I visited http://sunfreeware.blueyonder.co.uk/ to try
out the new frames functionality and noticed, in NS,
all of the text in the right-most frames is displayed
as Italic; it's shown "upright" in various other
PC-based browsers I've tried.

In NS, I have default font type set to "serif" and my
serif font is "Trinity".

Any ideas why?

Thanks,
James
tickets.summary: Sunfreeware Website shows Text in Italic, not Upright Text

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=906191

Yes; H5 in NetSurf is styled as:

h5 \{ display: block; font-size: medium; font-style: italic; margin: 1em 0; \}

by default. In the case of those pages, the H5 at the top is not closed until the end of the document, thus this style is propagating until another block-level element is encountered \(<p> in the case of the top frame, nothing in the case of the bottom frame\), hence the italic text.

Since submitting my last comment I've found another new version. This just gives an error message "Could not resolve host: http:calendar.google.com \(Domain name not found\)". I don't know what it was trying to resolve as a domain name, but it's an acceptable response.
Sorry about the dump. I can't upload a file if it's not my bug report.

tickets.description:
Clicking on an ad from Amazon's affiliate scheme causes the new window to inherit the iframe's size. Example here \(they're all over the place though\):

http://timworstall.typepad.com/timworstall/2005/09/this\_upcoming\_b.html
tickets.summary: Amazon ad links inherit iframe window size

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1055477
Originator: YES

If the zoom bar and the scale menu are not displayed then NS doesn't crash when the scale view > 100%. This happens e.g. if the street name is not spelled correctly. Multimap then opens a map where you can choose between 1 or more possibilities. NS doesn't crash when the scale view is changed, but as soon as you choose one of the possible locations, then NS tries to display \(a.o.\) the zoom bar and the scale menu \(above the map\) and it crashes.

\(I tried this with country=Belgium, Street=Rootenaard, Town=Lint\)

HTH

Stefaan

At http://dictionary.reference.com , the 'Dictionary.com' logo in the top left corner of the page seems to invisibly overlap the adjacent text entry box. This manifests as the mouse pointer shape changing to a finger rather than a caret whilst over the left end of the text box. Clicking in this side of the box text follows the link instead of positioning the caret.

The overlap is increased if the width of the window is reduced or the display scale is increased \(until eventually the 'Dictionary.com' graphic also visually overlaps the text box\).

tickets.description: If an image doesn't load properly e.g. on a page of thumbnails, but exists as a single pixel on the page, you can still follow a link on the image but you can't reload the image because when you click Menu on it the Object option is greyed out. With a site like photobucket.com it's hopeless to reload the whole page because you just get a different incomplete set of thumbnails every time.

The contents of frames is rendered incorrectly, but only the first time that the page is shown. Or possibly the first page that Netsurf renderes after it has been loaded.

Test case included. To reproduce the bug: Quit Netsurf and then double click the file "index.html" in the attached archive. The text in the left hand frame and the table in the right hand frame will be rendered incorrectly. For me, the text is off the left hand side of the frame, and the "width" element of the table has been ignored.

Resizing the window will cause the contents to be rendered correctly from then onwards, it seems.

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=430036
Originator: NO

I should think the site's changed.  The bug was caused by a self-redirect.  I'd think ns should be able to handle this, and use some sort of counter increment, and give up following redirects after the counter exceeds some value.  Even if the site now works, the problem's still valid.
posts.author: jamesshaw
posts.subject: #373 Bad redirect URL error

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1420374
Originator: NO

Another example of badly configured webserver leading to redirection problems is: type "www.davidpilling.net" + <Return> in the URL iconbar and see it getting more and more backslashes.  This is due:

\--8<--
\[23:49\] <jmb> Nettle: Looking up host www.davidpilling.net...
\[23:49\] <jmb> Nettle: Connecting to 85.234.133.167...
\[23:49\] <jmb> Nettle: Connected to 85.234.133.167
\[23:49\] <jmb> HEAD / HTTP/1.1
\[23:49\] <jmb> Host: www.davidpilling.net
\[23:49\] <jmb> HTTP/1.1 302 Found
\[23:49\] <jmb> Date: Tue, 10 Apr 2007 21:48:29 GMT
\[23:49\] <jmb> Server: Apache/1.3.37 \(Unix\) mod\_auth\_passthrough/1.8 mod\_log\_bytes/1.2 mod\_bwlimited/1.4 PHP/4.4.4 FrontPage/5.0.2.2635.SR1.2 mod\_ssl/2.8.28 OpenSSL/0.9.7a
\[23:49\] <jmb> Location: http://www.davidpilling.net//
\[23:49\] <jmb> Content-Type: text/html; charset=iso-8859-1
\[23:49\] <jmb> \(note the Location: header in the response\)
\[23:50\] <jmb> that said, NS should handle that sanely
\--8<--

The previously suggested redirection counter might have helped here or perhaps better sanity checking on "Location:" reply might be required instead.

tickets.description:
The URL http://list.mail.ru/10928/1/0\_1\_0\_1.html 
gives a message box reporting "IconvFailed: Invalid 
multibyte sequence".

A quick first-look revealed:

\[01:48\] <jmb> they've sent a GIF as text/plain with a 
charset of CP1251
\[01:48\] <jmb> hence the warning
\[01:49\] \* jmb wonders if it'd be better to simply log 
the error rather than reporting it to the user; they 
shouldn't really care, anyway
\[01:51\] <joty> I agree, the user doesn't care
\[01:51\] <jmb> trouble is; if they're actually loading 
a text document, they would care
\[01:51\] <jmb> and at the point the error happens, we 
can't tell the difference :/
\[01:56\] <jmb> actually; it shouldn't matter; if 
they're loading a text document, the browser window 
will be the owner and it'll handle the error for us
\[01:57\] <jmb> hm. I think our content handler error 
handling needs looking at; I'm not sure any of them 
should call warn\_user directly

Jo.

tickets.description:
The 05 Nov 2006 20:00 test build of NetSurf just crashed, leaving a log file in which the last message is "Termination signal received: Broken pipe". The symptoms are very similar to bug \#1519138, which has been closed. At the time I was browsing my Google mail inbox, and I believe that I had just clicked on a link to view an e-mail. I was browsing the BBC News web site at the same time.

NetSurf often crashes when I am using Google mail, but usually it just leaves a truncated log with no error message, register dump, or stack backtrace. It is unusual for it to record a coherent error message. I will attach the log file \(zipped\).

It is not so much the error that is irritating \(perhaps it is legitimate\), but the fact that it is fatal and NetSurf does not report it properly.

tickets.description:
You might like to experiment looking at my website:
http://www.nyetimberweather.org.uk/
which currently uses FRAMES.
o  The top frame has NORESIZE set but this does not work in NS.
o  Adjusting the bottom of the central frame won't adjust below a certain place.
o  When dragging the bottom of the central frame up, it should stop at the top of the central frame but it continues up to the top of the top frame.
o  The page title does not show in the window's title bar.
o  The top graphic initially appears to the left off of centre - resizing the window however knocks it into place in the centre.
o  Clicking the NS windows's full size icon does not respond as expected.
o  Clicking the page 'refresh' icon seldom seems to work.  The site updates every 15 minutes \(when the PC is on\) and the upload time is shown at the bottom of each weather graphic.
o  If you drag the window resize icon to and fro horizontally, you will see some text behind the sky graphic in the top frame.  This text matches the following statement at the beginning of the index.html page - <\!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01 Frameset//EN" "http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/frameset.dtd">

Using:
\--------
Iyonix PC with RISC OS 5.11 and 512MB memory
NetSurf - 7 Nov 2006 22:00
bernard@bapfish.org.uk

tickets.description:
Viewing this site http://www.teesvalleyregeneration.co.uk/

the whole of the right side of the page appears wrongly, This happens in Wikipedia, though never so disastrously as this. 

I am using Test build 11 Nov, 2006, 20 00, downloaded today

Michael Bell

michael@beaverbell.co.uk

td valign="top" doesn't appear to be working correctly in recent builds - I'm testing with 11 Nov 2006 20:00 build.

For an example, visit http://wildlife.vigay.com and look at the three rows of thumbnail images. All three rows should be top aligned, but the bottom row are out - presumably because there are two lines of text on the last couple of images?

Paul Vigay \(nospam@vigay.com\)

If an image with a link on it is constrained by height and width arguments to a smaller size than it actually is then the hit area for the link extends to the right and below the bounds of the image, probably to the original size of the image. It is probable that the converse applies if the image is stretched beyond its original size but I haven't tested this.

tickets.description:
A background colour is applied to table rows but not to the table itself. A cell spans two rows. In that cell the background colour is only applied to the area contained within the first row, not to the whole of the cell. See attached file.

Attrributes applied to a row must be applied to each cell defined in that row inless overridden in the cell tag \(or in the case of row height by the cell contents forcing the row to be higher\), regardless of whether those cells span subsequent rows.

1\. Test build 4. Dec, 02:15 \(and all previous builds I have tried out\)

2\. Iyonix, RO5.11

3\. http://www.bildungsportal.nrw.de/BP/STELLA

Scrolling and clicking on links is possible, but all pages that can be reached through these links show the same behaviour.



JochenKonietzko@gmx.de

I have sometimes noticed that Netsurf displays incorrect images when pages are loaded. Today I found one on the BBC news site. I have a screen grab and a full-save of the page affected.
