tickets.description:
With apologies for the ludicrous length of this URL:

http://www.dh.gov.uk/PublicationsAndStatistics/Publications/PublicationsPolicyAndGuidance/PublicationsPAmpGBrowsableDocument/fs/en?CONTENT\_ID=4097241&MULTIPAGE\_ID=4912278&chk=kcvxqz

\(I did try to use makeashorterurl, but found another bug ;-\)

This gives a warning in the message bar:

Warning: stylesheet is not CSS

and hourglasses extensively. It does eventually display the page after
a couple of minutes \(Iyonix\), but apparently without any styling applied.

The Firefox debugger reports no problems with the page or the CSS
\(which consists of multiple @includes, many of which contain CRLF 
linefeeds\). 

10 Dec build, RO 5.11

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=826159
Originator: NO

Changing the default type to text/plain has fixed the long period of hourglassing.
posts.author: tlsa
posts.subject: #426 Possible CSS problem

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=826159
Originator: NO

Closing this as the URL nolonger seems to work.

The issue was that there was no content-type header with the CSS. Now it is treated as text, rather than HTML, so there is no long period of hourglassing. Content-type sniffing has not been implemented in NetSurf \(as the spec. says it shouldn't be\). There are several other items on the tracker about implementing content-type sniffing so this bug may as well be closed.

Thanks for reporting.
posts.author: tlsa
posts.subject: #426 Possible CSS problem

posts.text:

The source you speak of is all confined to small areas that don't obscure the page's content. In fact they are all adverts that the web server is sending as text/plain. NetSurf is technically behaving correctly by displaying them as text.

I'm closing this bug because it doesn't crash now.

If you want to request the feature that NetSurf 'sniffs content', deciding itself what type of file it is, then please make a feature request. I think it is unlikely to happen though, because the specification specifically forbids content sniffing. The developers are also aware of the issue.

Thanks for reporting.

tickets.description:
Exhibited on the BBC News website where onmouseover command text is sometimes displayed between image navigation buttoms at the bottom of the page.

Example; http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/shared/spl/hi/pop\_ups/07/uk\_stricken\_ship/html/1.stm moving through the images by pressing next or previous or clicking on the numbered buttons will cause the fault to occur randomly. It is not a fault on indivisual pages, as apart from the image name and text, they are otherwise identical \(and contain exactly the same W3C validation errors\).

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=453739
Originator: NO

This is due to a bug in libxml2. It occurs when the chunks of data received are split at a certain point in the file, so only happens some of the time.

I've reported the bug upstream:

http://bugzilla.gnome.org/show\_bug.cgi?id=444994

In both cases a slight adjustment of the window size with the bottom-right icon or a click on the refresh button restores the correct display. If you then click  the maximise icon again the same thing happens.  I am using RISC OS 4.03 on a Kinetic RISC PC \(in case that may be relevant\).  If you wish to contact me please use the email address <aux.auges@free.fr>.

Wrote it up, and dropped zip file on the wrong box on the SourceForge submission form. Splat.

The text of the original bug report is in the Netsurf log file, but it's so buried by other internal data I can't face digging it out again.

The text I originaly wrote seems to begin at

0x72709bc4 x0 y22 w48 h22 \(0 0 48 22\) TEXT 0 'URLs:'

There was about 5 paragraphs worth.

So, one bugs inside the bug report for another\!

Log file and sample pages from parslow.com are also linked to at http://www.simon-smith.org/Netsurf.zip \(Note capital letter, netsurf.zip is for another bug report, still open.\)

posts.author: cjt02
posts.subject: #465 Indirect document self-reference badness

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=906191
Originator: NO

This may be fixed in the latest version. It's a bit hacky though, and I'm not sure I like the fix.

Summary of the issue:

The page in question includes itself \(probably indirectly through a CSS file\) as a CSS document. NetSurf detects that the content type is not permissible in the relevant context and thus ignores the "stylesheet". It does this by simply having the owning content remove itself from the user list of the bad one; leaving the bad content alone for content\_clean\(\) to have its way with next time it's called. In the meantime, however, the bad content is still being fetched, parsed, etc. As it's the same document, we get some nice recursion going on, which eats memory until there is no more.

Summary of the current workaround:

As the content's in error, once the parent has removed itself from the user list, it explicitly checks to see if there are no further registered users of the content. If there are none, then it forcibly stops the fetch and marks the bad content as being in error. I'm not 100% sure this catches all cases, however, and it certainly doesn't solve the generic issue of indirected self-reference \(there are already checks all over the place for direct self-reference, as this is easy to do and fairly common\). 

Perhaps a more robust solution would be to do the following:

In fetchcache\(\), traverse the parent content list up to the root. If the URL for the fetch being attempted is encountered, don't bother to fetch at all. This traversal needs to cover all registered users of the immediate parent content.
Unfortunately, this doesn't cater for the case where the server serves up the same document from differing URLs \(e.g. when different GET parameters are specified\). Quite how we're meant to deal with that, I've no idea at present.

tickets.description:
utils/filename.c makes use of the d\_type field in struct dirent, which is a BSD extension, and prevents NetSurf building under Solaris, and most likely other esoteric UNIX variants.

Ideally, this code should be reworked to stat\(\) where it needs to know the type, and use the IS\_DIR\(\) macro instead.
tickets.summary: utils/filename.c makes use of BSD extensions

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=893271
Originator: YES

tickets.description:
The 'vspace' attribute for <img> tags appears to be ignored by Netsurf; it's quite hard to demonstrate visually since it also ignores the border attribute and the image size settings\!  Fresco and Oregano add extra vertical space both above and below the image in the attached example, WebsterXL adds it below, and Netsurf seems to do nothing at all.

It makes no difference whether the image is found or \(as in this case\) it is missing, save that the absence of surrounding space is rather more obvious when the image is actually displayed; is this a case of deprecated code now expected to be implemented via CSS sheets?

tickets.description: Just crashed and dumped on going to a new story in a new window.

It looks like NetSurf is not parsing \(or ignoring\) duff HTML in between <option> tags in drop-down menus in online forms. The inclusion of a <p> tag seems to 'finish the form' resulting in no further items being listed.

Not sure if I'm describing this correctly, but you can see an example at http://postmaster.info.aol.com/tools/fbl.html where there's a menu list to select confirmation email \(@FBL Domain\) but there is only the 'Choose' option and you can't get to the other options \(resulting in the form being rejected when you submit it\).

Looking at the HTML, there is no horrible Javascript or anything and the only 'mistake' I can find are <p> tags between menu options.

Hope this is enough info. You can contact me at nospam \(at\) vigay.com

Paul \(Vigay\)

posts.text:

This may not be relevant to the original query but may be to Paul's comment:

I also had a self-written HTTP server that stopped working at about this time; I needed to add a \(required by RFC\) 'Connection: Close' to my response header to make it work again which implies that the change in libraries meant that persistent connection handling was changed.

HTTP/1.1 applications that do not support persistent connections MUST include the "close" connection option in every message.

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1577829
Originator: NO

Those "\(?\)" links use javascript to pop open a new window. Of course NetSurf doesn't do JS, but it appears that it's parsing part of the javascript as a valid URL.

If you want to ensure you open something in a new window, get into the habit of right \(adjust\) clicking on links :\)

tickets.description:
Recent builds of Netsurf display a habit of single-tasking for extended periods while 'secondary' downloads are taking place, i.e. progress indicated to the right of the main percentage display at the bottom of the page.   While this is happening nothing on the entire desktop updates except for the figures on Netsurf's progress indicator, which change very rapdily in tenths of a second.

This seems to happen with great regularity, and makes the browser rather hard to use on a dial-up connection.

posts.text:
Logged In: NO 

I've noticed this as well. I am not sure if there is more single-tasking but I have had to revert to a test build, as the release build doesn't show the hourglass which makes it harder to judge if clicks and drags are queued for action.

I also, occasionally, see only the status bar updating without the content area even being displayed.

Does this only happen on particular, regularly visited, sites?

Please try:
1\. Quit NetSurf
2\. Rename or move your cookies file away \(Choices:WWW.NetSurf.Cookies\)
3\. Run NetSurf and check for single tasking symptom

Is it faster without your cookies file?

Remember to quit NetSurf before restoring your old cookies file.

I was going to say that deleting the old Cookies file had produced a speed-up, but then I tried logging into Sourceforge, and found the problem there just as bad as ever before.   :-\(   As a test, I quit Netsurf, deleted those few cookies that had accumulated in the course of my tests last night, and reloaded the bug tracker page with no Cookies file at all - the desktop still single-tasks when the secondary download starts.   It's easy to tell the difference, because during the normal 'primary' download you can resize the Netsurf window; after it starts doing the extra stuff, the window stops responding.

tickets.description:
Load a page with graphics on it.

Click-drag in the page, and the mouse pointer should change to a hand icon, allowing you to drag-scroll the page up and down, if it's big enough.

Menu-click a graphic on the page, select Object->Save->Save as

Drag and drop the file icon somewhere useless, like an empty area on the task bar or the pinboard, thereby producing an aborted save.

Now try click-dragging again anywhere in the page, and you should get the hand icon again for an instant, and an immediate crash of Netsurf.  In practice of course, the tiniest movement when clicking could get  interpreted as a drag-scroll. Thereafter, the next inadvertent click-drag, /even  several pages later/ will provoke a crash. Log files available if needed, but  this is now 100% repeatable for me.

\(Tested with gif, png and jpg, may well apply to any aborted save.\)
tickets.summary: Aborted save provokes crash on next click-drag

tickets.description:
1\. Drag and drop an ArtWorks format file onto NetSurf. It displays in an otherwise 'raw' window. Now attempt to export the page as a DrawFile. \(Ctrl-Shift-F3\) You end up with an empty 24- or 48- byte Draw file, and the ArtWorks image drawn across the raw desktop. Hardly a serious bug, but obviously not desirable.

2\. As 1., but using a Draw file instead. Exact same behaviour.

3\. Drag an animated gif file onto Netsurf. It displays in a 'raw' window. Zoom in to 200%. Admire animation. Drag another animated gif into the same window. It /will/ be displayed animated, but it does /not/ respect the window's 200% zoom factor. Also pretty minor.

Haven't repeated any of these with actual web pages rather than just raw graphics files, but thought I'd flag them anyway.

sometime pre
14/05/2013

tickets.description:
This could be the cause of a lot of formatting problems where text overwrites other text of images.

NetSurf fails to cope adequately with empty table rows, i.e. "<tr></tr>" with no table cells. This seems to cause the next valid table row to overwrite the previous one. OK this is bad html but it is obvious what the author wants \(a gap\). If NS chooses to ignore the faulty row it should just ignore it and not overwrite the previous good row.

On the attached page, if you replace all occurrences of "<tr></tr>" by "<tr><td></td></tr>" the page formats correctly.

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=999199
Originator: NO

This issue should now be fixed. Thanks for the detailed bug report. R.

tickets.description: NetSurf aborted when idle. No windoiws were open. I was running \!EXIFinfo when the abort happened. Log attached.

When NetSurf exports a page as a draw file, the font names are incorrect \(I just verified with Castle\).
For instance, Homerton.Bold\EUTF8

The fontname shouldn't have \EUTF8 at the end, and this is preventing the Drawfile from being subsequently printed via \!Printers.

This is using NetSurf2 29th Aug 00:30 build.

Paul \(Vigay\)
tickets.summary: Incorrect font names in exported !Draw files

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=453739
Originator: NO

This is intentional. NetSurf on RISC OS 5 creates Drawfiles that contain Unicode text encoded using UTF8, so it sets the encoding on the font identifier.

Unfortunately Printers on RO5 does not support UTF8 when using a PostScript printer.

James

NetSurf \(30 Sep 2007\) r3613 displays my Yahoo Mail inbox page so that it is readable, but NetSurf \(04 Oct 2007\) r3622, and subsequent versions, display it as a completely blank \(white\) page. The page html is in the zip attachment.

posts.author: old_coaster
posts.subject: #625 yahoo mail rendered as blank page

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=826159
Originator: NO

OK, yahoo is giving you a version of its web mail which uses JavaScript. Something's causing that page not to be shown at all. The real issue is that the HEAD element contains a META refresh which should take you to the non-JS version of the web mail. NetSurf doesn't follow this redirection because the META refresh is in a NOSCRIPT element. NetSurf ignores NOSCRIPT contents in HEAD.
posts.author: tlsa
posts.subject: #625 yahoo mail rendered as blank page

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1384902
Originator: YES

So why is it that NetSurf \(30 Sep 2007\) r3613, and previous versions do
\_not\_ display a blank page?

Was there an 'error' in r3613 which allowed it to follow the re-direct?
If so, could the 'error' please be reinstated?

Tony
posts.author: old_coaster
posts.subject: #625 yahoo mail rendered as blank page

posts.text: NetSurf has long searched for meta refreshes deeply nested in the tree. Thus, this is out of date. If you're still getting a blank page, then please open a new bug report.

tickets.description:
Cut-and-paste from a NetSurf window into the URL bar adds one extra spurious character to the end of whatever you paste. If what you pasted was a filename, the presence of the extra character is likely to cause a file not found response from the remote server.

To replicate this minor issue:

Open a page with an external link on it \(e.g. of the form <a href="http://www.example.com/index.html">. View source. Drag-select the link text for the link. \(i.e. Just the bit inside the double quotes.\) Save the selection from the editor window onto the Netsurf iconbar  icon. A new NetSurf window will open, with a file:/// URL pointing to a ScrapFile, containing the pasted URL.

In the new NetSurf window, drag-select exactly the text of the link and drop it into the URL entry box. While the page is loading, click the mouse to the right of the pasted URL. You will see that there is a spurious character there. A hard space? A null? Hard to tell. If the link was to a web directory-level link \(link ending in /\) the page should still load. If the link is of the form http://www.example.com/index.html or http://www.example.com/image.png the link will probably not work because the extra spurious character is treated as part of the filename. You have to delete the extra character and retry. Seems to occur any time you cut and paste from within a NetSurf window into the URL field.

I had an unusual experience today. I tried to quit NetSurf from the icon bar menu but it wouldn't quit. I then noticed that there was a status bar at the bottom of the screen with the clock counting up but nothing received. The bar couldn't be moved. There were no other parts of that window or other NS windows open. I then used Alt-Break to kill NetSurf.

The log ends with thousands of identical lines containing:

content/fetch.c fetch\_send\_callback 557: Fetcher sending callback. Fetch 0x3a5fb578, fetcher 0x3a2392a0 data 0x2fef90 size 0

When I try to open Multimap, Netsurf exits without properly opening. No error log is produced

It is version \(Dev\)\(05 Nov 2007 15:45\) r3651

Michael Bell

michael@beaverbell.co.uk

http://episteme.arstechnica.com/eve
NetSurf r3651, 05/11/2007
RISC OS 4.02

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=906191

The visibility property inherits, so nothing gets rendered.

If you then look at the style sheet \(normal.css\) you will see that the red cells \(class charindex\_simpable\) have a td rule which contains font-size 24px, the blue ones have a td rule which contains NO font size while the black ones have a 4px font size.

posts.subject: #658 Can no longer drop a text file containing links

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=906191
Originator: NO

The way in which URLs are extracted from text files dropped on the toolbar is pretty simple:

1\) Strip any leading whitespace
2\) Read up until the end of the data or a CR/LF \(whichever comes first\)
3\) Try to launch the resulting string as an URL

It currently performs no sanity checking that the text it's read actually is an URL.

Thus, if the file you drop on the toolbar doesn't contain an URL as the first line, then it won't have any effect. This behaviour hasn't been changed for a very long time.

The full save problem is due to the page claiming to be utf-8 encoded, then using non-utf-8 text. This causes the parser used for full save to except loudly. It's a known issue which will be fixed in due course.

A workaround was put in place yesterday for NetBSD. Thanks.

Some other symbol/macro was defined that caused the NetBSD default to not be defined.

Some more details on problem are here:
http://mail-index.netbsd.org/current-users/2008/03/13/msg001342.html

tickets.description:
I am using Netsurf version 2.0 \(Dev\) \(14 Mar 2008 10:15\) r3950, on a Risc PC running RISC OS 6. I have as-yet been unable to reproduce the problem. It may have been related to lack of memory, because I had many pages open at the time.

Netsurf crashed with a segmentation fault whilst apparently trying to display an MNG image fetched from http://tn3-2.deviantart.com/fs19/300W/f/2007/305/4/4/My\_composing\_desktop\_by\_swirlythingy.png
However, if I just fetch this URL on its own then I instead get a friendly dialogue box saying 'PNG library error'. The website's URL is http://swirlythingy.deviantart.com/

Fatal signal received: Segmentation fault

Stack backtrace:

Running thread 0x2ff864

Clicked on a link to The Register from my local home page. NS dumped with a "serious error". April 14th build.

Richard \(minijem\)

Sorry, I'm not going to struggle with Sourceforge's wretched login.

On my sites I use form submits with PHP code behind and generate a reply with a header like this:

Location: mailto:my@email.address

With previous NetSurf versions this worked flawlessly, far more better than with every other browser I have found \(the other browsers all show the site content of that page, which contains alternative instructions of how to contact one, \_and\_ open a mailer, whereas NetSurf just opened the mailer like an ordinary mailto: link would have done\).

However, recent NetSurf versions don't do this anymore, but just react with:

Sorry, NetSurf was unable to display this page

The address mailto:my@email.address could not be understood.

You can test this behaviour e.g. on the bottom right of
http://www.sbellon.de/

tickets.description:
Using build 4100 an svg document which has text elements renders a LF before the text. The source document reads in part -

<text ....... >
Fred</text>

This is the style in which ArtWorks generates text - starting the actual text on a new line.

If I edit the document to make the text content run on after the start tag then the LF disappears - suggesting that leading whitespace is not being removed during parsing as it should be.

Keith Hopper

tickets.description:
Select some text which had a yellow background, and it changes to a white background. The foreground colour \(black\) remains the same. This means it is indistinguishable from text which had no background set \(assuming a white body\). Surely Netsurf should not display selected text with the same background as the page itself.
This is most easily demonstrated by going to any cached google search result, where the search terms appear with yellow/blue/green backgrounds, and selecting some paragraphs.
epring

Searching a web page using 'find text' works immediately as I start typing in characters in the search box. However, if I use the menu of previously chosen search terms to choose the same term, nothing is automatically selected in the document. Pressing return afterwards doesn't help.
Can be demonstrated using the very page I am looking at now - sourceforge bug tracker input - and searching for the text 'user', but probably also any web page.
I think the problem lies with the automatic selecting not happening or showing. I think the search is actually being performed, because if the search term appears more than once, the 'Next' button lights up, whereas if it doesn't it doesn't.
epring

tickets.description:
NetSurf 1.2 won't load any page on Fedora 9, it just says "Opening page..." with the throbber animation running.

I think this is due to a change in libcurl 7.18.1 
\(http://curl.haxx.se/changes.html\):

\- setting the CURLOPT\_SSL\_CTX\_FUNCTION with libcurl built without OpenSSL now makes curl\_easy\_setopt\(\) properly return failure

Fedora 8 used libcurl 7.16 which would explain why this works. Fedora 8 and 9's libcurl packages appears to be built against NSS for SSL support.

With lines 614 and 615 of content/fetchers/fetch\_curl.c commented out pages are loaded.
tickets.summary: Fails to load pages on Fedora 9

posts.text: We've worked around this in the buildsystem. The long term fix requires libcurl 7.19.x to be shipped by distributions.

The machine has 128+2MB RAM. Loading NetSurf, after a clean boot, reduces this to 104MB free.

However, I now find that if the PNG is dropped into NetSurf, \_before\_ displaying the etext \(ie when 104MB RAM is free\) then the PNG \_does\_ display without error. I am surprised that so much RAM is needed.

So your implied guess - too little memory - is correct, and this is not primarily a NetSurf problem. Many thanks for your rapid response.

Tony
posts.author: old_coaster
posts.subject: #757 png file crashes netsurf

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=453739
Originator: NO

NetSurf needs enough memory to store the uncompressed image as a Sprite, which is approx. 70MB.

It shouldn't have crashed, and I've fixed this in r4237. You should now get an out of memory warning.

James

why doesn't NetSurf release the memory when

quit NetSurf                109MB free

tickets.description: This time when i clicked on a link on my local home page.

Crashes on following URL

http://www.novatech.co.uk/novatech/specpage.html?NOV-LCD24A

If you edit a text area, and then try to drag-select it, the selection becomes disrupted in some places. It is unable to select some portions and wants to skip to the next line.

This is due to selection\_label\_subtree not being called when the text is changed. Currently it is only called whe n s->root is changed \(as in clicking in another part of the page\).

This also affects select\_all as selection->max\_idx is only recalculated when selection\_label\_subtree is called. This allows max\_idx to be greater than the length of the text box when text is deleted.

To reproduce:
copy this text
"Whether you want to check your webmail, read the news or post to discussion forums, NetSurf is your lightweight gateway to the world wide web. Actively developed, NetSurf is continually evolving and improving."

and go to: http://www.mcfedries.com/CreatingAWebPage/textarea.htm
paste it in that text area at the bottom and delete the word "developed", then try to select that line.
tickets.summary: Subtree is not relabeled when text boxes change

There is no bug report attached here, just a zip of the NetSurf log file.  This does not constitute a bug report.  A bug report contains information about what you were doing, how, if the issue is repeatable, what system you are using, which NetSurf you are using, which other sites show similar issues, etc etc etc.

Please do not file bug reports containing just the log.  As I've said before, they're a waste of everybody's time.  I suggest you read http://www.chiark.greenend.org.uk/~sgtatham/bugs.html - it's quite a long read, but essential none the less for anybody who wishes to report bugs in a useful, constructive manner.

posts.text: I notice that in 3.1 (CI #1316), for example, and using only standard Acorn fonts, neither <sub> nor <sup> tag contents are rendered correctly as sub- and super-scripts  Is this a local problem, or an abiding deficiency in RISC OS Netsurf?
posts.author: bernarduk
posts.subject: #792 Subscript text is displayed as superscript

posts.text:
In message
</p/netsurf/bugs/792/e2908e66688858763aaf814d96ca3cf640062ce7.bugs@netsurf.p.sourceforge.net>
          "Bernard Boase" <bernarduk@users.sf.net> wrote:

> I notice that in 3.1 (CI #1316), for example, and using only standard Acorn
> fonts, neither sub- nor super-scripts are rendered correctly. Is this a
> local problem, or an abiding deficiency in RISC OS Netsurf?
>
>
>---
>
>** [bugs:#792] Subscript text is displayed as superscript**
>
>**Status:** open
>**Created:** Mon Aug 04, 2008 07:25 PM UTC by Dave Higton
>**Last Updated:** Mon Aug 04, 2008 07:25 PM UTC
>**Owner:** nobody
>
>Both subscript and superscript text are displayed as superscript.

I just wrote a small test file, and found that both superscript
and subscript are rendered correctly in #1391.  I think it was
fixed a long time ago.

How much difference there is between the super/subscript and normal
characters may depend on the font in use.  There wasn't as much
difference as I expected, but the main font size was not many pixels
high in my experiment.

Perhaps one of the NS developers would care to comment?

Dave

posts.text:
Logged In: NO 

This may be related to a transient problem I have seen at the beginning of a table where above the table at the left on a line of its own appears a single character - often the digit '8'.

I thought I had traced this to being a charset problem \(RISCOS vis-a-vis utf8 - some 'invisible' character code - but the artefact is always outside the table area and I have not, as yet, been able to pin-point what is causing it - attempt a fix and it goes away never to come back - until the next document. No other browser shows the artefact \(Firefox, Opera, Konqueror, Amaya, etc\). Might this be a buffer flushing to the rendered document which is expected to be empty but isn't?

Keith Hopper
asgard@inspire.net.nz
posts.author: nobody
posts.subject: #833   rendering odd artifacts

posts.text: Fixed by using lpu internal encoding stuff instead of iconv. Thanks for reporting.

posts.author: minijem
posts.subject: #856 Master bug for crashes experienced by minijem

posts.text:
In order to deal with the crashes you're seeing, we would like to manage the communication in one place. I have chosen this bug as the place. Please don't submit any new bugs. Instead add comments to this bug.

Please download the special debug build at http://zamez.org/netsurf-debug.zip

When NetSurf crashes, it will produce 3 files additional to the log file in your root or current directory: dmalloc\_log, NetSurf\_Slot, and NetSurf\_DA. Please email those and the log to me directly for the next 1 crash only, except if it has hubbub in the backtrace at the end of the log.

James
posts.author: bursa
posts.subject: #856 Master bug for crashes experienced by minijem

posts.text:
- **priority**: 5 --> 7
- **assigned_to**: nobody --> bursa
- **summary**: Segmentation Fault --> Master bug for crashes experienced by minijem
- **status**: open --> open-accepted
posts.author: bursa
posts.subject: #856 Master bug for crashes experienced by minijem

posts.text: I'm trying my hardest to crash it, but the debug version seems pretty bullet-proof at the moment, if a bit slow\! -minijem

posts.subject: #856 Master bug for crashes experienced by minijem

posts.text:
Hi Richard,

After discussion with the other developers we are convinced that the vast majority of these crashes must be due to a serious problem with the hardware that you are using.

We haven't been able reproduce any of them, and the pattern and frequency of crashes is unique to your reports. The test builds that we sent you found no software bugs. I'm sorry, but there's nothing we can do to solve this, and more reports or log files are not going to change that.

Therefore we're going to close this and the other similar bugs. We request that you don't report more crashes until you replace your hardware.

James

tickets.description:
NetSurf 2.0 \(Dev\) \(11 Sep 2008 21:45\) r5304

When any 'new-look' Register news-page \(eg http://www.theregister.co.uk/2008/09/17/reiss\_leaves\_rs/ \) is full-saved, the file version of the page does not display correctly.

This occurs because the source html of the page contains
<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="http://www.theregister.co.uk/style\_picker/design"> which NetSurf fails to convert into a local link, although the css file 'style\_picker/design' \_is\_ saved as '36d177d8', or whatever.

Tony

posts.text:
To see the problem, using r5369:

1 full-save any news page from the Register,
2 take the computer off-line,
3 load the file copy of the Register page.

You will find that the formatting of the file copy page is bizarre.

Step 2, above, is necessary to prevent NetSurf loading the CSS file from the net \(in the file copy html, the link to the CSS file still points to the net, instead of the file copy of the CSS file\).

Tony

tickets.description:
Visiting Amazon.co.uk today the page doesnt display properly at all.
All the text/options/menus on the left side is all on top of each other.
The search box on the top is repeated around 10 times all the way along.

http://news.cnet.com/8301-13739\_3-10030134-46.html

If "Hide advertisements" is ticked, various items from near the bottom of the page are superimposed over items near the top of the page, rendering them illegible.

NS r5632, Iyonix, RO 5.11, 512 MB.  Perfectly repeatable, was originally reported in netsurf-users by Paul Vigay.

Netsurf \(21 Oct r5612\) seems to be having some trouble with the IMDb's
MyMovies feature.   Copying films from one 'category' \(list of film
entries\) to another no longer works, and nor do attempts to create new
categories. Both worked the last time I tried them \(on earlier versions
of NetSurf\) and still work with WebsterXL with JavaScript disabled - so
it can't be a case of newly-introduced JavaScript dependency...

This behaviour can be demonstrated on a sample account: go to
http://imdb.com and log in as user 'Cunarder', password 'websterxl',
then select "Cunarder's account" from the various options at the top of
the page.   Click on 'Update MyMovies' \(in centre column\) and you should
see a list of 8 titles under the heading "Cunarder's Movies".

Select an appropriate title by clicking on the option icon to its left,
select the empty category 'Depp' from the menu icon at the bottom of the
list, and attempt to copy the title into that category by clicking the
'Copy' button.

What \*should\* happen is that the page reopens to display the new
contents of the destination category;  what actually happens on Netsurf
is that the page reopens on the same list, and the title is not copied
to the destination category at all \(as can be established by clicking on
the 'Depp' entry listed on the left of the page\).

The attached archive contains three logs obtained in succession by actions which I have noted in the first few lines of each file.

All crashes occurred during initialisation of Netsurf \(r5632\) before the icon appeared on the icon bar.

I suspect that the first crash did something nasty in memory and the following recursive SIGSEGVs were consequential - nasty\!

Keith Hopper
asgard@inspire.net.nz

The 'Update' feature on the IMDb no longer seems to work with Netsurf.   Clicking on the Update button on any of the relevant pages leads to a page with a single unlabelled checkbox and 'Cancel' and 'Choose again' buttons, instead of the expected drop-down menu icon with appropriate selections for that section of the film database...   The actual HTML served up to Netsurf seems to be different, not merely the browser's rendering of it\!

To demonstrate:
go to the URL https://secure.imdb.com/register-imdb/login and log in as the sample user 'Cunarder', password 'websterxl'

Visit the page http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0058007/trivia   \(Trivia for the 1964 horror movie 'Devil Doll'\)
Click on the yellow 'Update' icon at the bottom of the page.

Under the heading 'Fun Stuff' at the bottom of the new page you should see a drop-down menu list that currently reads 'No change'; select 'Add one item' from this menu and click on the 'Continue' icon.

You ought now to see a long list of instructions, with a writable icon at the bottom into which the new data can be typed.

Using Netsurf, what you see is a blank page beneath the standard IMDb header, with a single unlabelled checkbox and a pair of 'Cancel' and 'Continue' buttons - no way of actually entering any data\!

tickets.description:
I've found a repeatable crash in NetSurf's RISC OS Choices windows.

Steps to reproduce:

1\) Load NS
2\) Go to the choices window
3\) Open the first six windows up at teh same time
4\) Close the original NS Configuration window

NetSurf crashes every time at this.

In some combinations of choices windows, it will instead let you close the original choices window, but then none of the cancel buttons will work to close the dialogues, and NS will crash when you try and re-open the choices window.

I've attached the resulting log that NS gives when you force kill teh task using alt-break.

Andy.

1\) Ensure we currently have no 401 authentication details.
2\) POST a form to a resource protected by HTTP Basic Auth, say.

John

Viewing this page in other browsers, some of the images of houses are overlaid with PNG banners reading "Under offer".  In NetSurf 2.1 and the latest test build \(28th May 2009\) the "Under offer" PNGs are not visible,
I assume they must be being rendered underneath the images of the houses concerned.  Some of them appear briefly while the page is loading, but disappear as soon as the image they're supposed to be on top of has been loaded.

As the stylesheet is not included in the page source I can't see at a glance what bit of code NetSurf is having trouble with.

Thanks for looking into this\!

This same page also shows up three problems with Draw file export:
\(1\) the TSPC logo \(which is a GIF\) loses its transparency and is mostly black.
\(2\) the white-on-blue links across the top end up somewhere off-screen to the left of the rest of the page.
\(3\) and the white-on-blue links just end up as plain ordinary blue text, i.e. they lose their style sheet formatting.

posts.author: arturjar
posts.subject: #953 Can't write capital or special characters

posts.text:
that is problem because SDL is not switch in unicode mode.
read here

http://lists.libsdl.org/pipermail/sdl-libsdl.org/2004-October/046782.html

i do in netsurf in fb\_os\_init

that line

SDL\_EnableUNICODE\(true\);

and later in fb\_os\_input change to this

... event.key.keysym.unicode;

the shift alt work then as expectet.but national chars dont work, but that seem Bug in amiga 68k sdl.games that allow player names use always EnableUnicide, and here too language special chars are not print

tickets.description:
When a file: protocol address is specified along with a hostname part, NetSurf incorrectly takes the hostname as the first component of the path.
eg. file://localhost/path/file becomes file:///localhost/path/file \(ie. path is now /localhost/path/file instead of /path/file\)

Notes from jmb's list email on the subject:
\--8<--
It's not quite that simple. There needs to be a reliable way of knowing
that file://localhost/<path> really is requesting <path> on the local
host, rather than "localhost" being the top-level component of the path.
Most likely, the correct solution is some kind of DNS lookup \(as you'd
expect file://<hostname>/<path> to also work, where <hostname> is
whatever the current host's name is\).
\--8<--

NB: amiga/misc.c r9656 contains a workaround for this issue in the Amiga port, which will probably need to be reverted back to r5695 when there is a proper solution in place.

tickets.description:
In some circumstances NetSurf generates the wrong file name when saving a file downloaded from a web page. This usually happens when the file is delivered by a content management system. Conversely when you save the link as a URI for example, the uri file is saved with the correct filename of the target file.
An example of this can be found on page
http://www.raib.gov.uk/publications/investigation\_reports/reports\_2009/report332009.cfm
Click on the link under "Download report". The file is saved as cms\_resources/cfm.
However if you save the link as a URI the file is named 091214\_R332009\_North\_Rode.pdf which is the correct name of the target file.
The URI file contains URL http://www.raib.gov.uk/cms\_resources/091214\_R332009\_North\_Rode.pdf

posts.text:
Note that double-clicking on the URI file produces exactly the same effect. The anchor tag for the link is
<a target="\_blank" class="siteAibReportLink" href="/cms\_resources/091214\_R332009\_North\_Rode.pdf">

tickets.description: NS aborted with two 'serious error' messages before dumping.

On some sites, the plotting of images in the vertical direction is too short \(not all image displayed\).

I can reproduce this on the OS4 and GTK versions of NetSurf and have seen it on two sites - screenshots attached.

On http://www.nintendolife.com the "featured review" image shows this problem.
On http://www.amiga-look.org the main heading banner shows a hatched area below where NetSurf thinks the bottom of the image and text links should be.

I think these are both the same issue but they might not be.

posts.text:
The amiga-look one was a bug in the vertical positioning of absolute positioned inlines using the static position. \(It got rendered too far down the page, causing other content further down the page to obscure the bottom of the image.\)

This is fixed in r10495.

The nintendolife one is actually that the site renders another \(semi-transparent\) box on top of the image using the z-index and opacity properties. Neither of these properties are currently implemented in the layout engine. The opacity property is CSS3, which we've not started on. The z-index property is just not done yet and I'm not sure if it will be done with the existing layout engine, as it requires quite a lot of changes. So those are both features that are still on the TODO list.

I'll close this since the bug was fixed, and we're aware of the other issues.

ADFS::HardDisc4.$.rap.MMPA.RAIB.cms\_resources/cfm

As described on the mailing list:

As suggested by John-Mark Bell, this \*does\* appear to be a configuration problem.

To get https: to work I did the following:
\- Deleted Boot:Choices:WWW.Netsurf
\- Loaded NetSurf
\- Under Configuration, click 'Set' on any setting \(in fact, I've not tried them \*all\* but am now satisfied that it's not just a case of, e.g. changing the cache size, as I found at first.
\- Quit and reload

I'm happy to have a look at the sources but as I'm still getting things up and running and don't exactly have adequate programming experience, it'll be a while before I do.

Thanks for the continuing enthusiasm with NetSurf - I hope there's some way to keep the RO front end up to date in the longer term.

Cheers

Trevor Johnson

posts.author: tlsa
posts.subject: #1091 Frequent crashes on Burda.com site (cookies?)

posts.text:
You're right - it's almost definitely a cookie issue. Deleting cookies for this site caused the pages to load many, many times faster, for a start\! \(the log-in page alone took about three minutes to render before cookie deletion....\)

I'm afraid it also appears to be something to do with being logged in. I have managed to get the site to crash twice so far with the latest Netsurf release \(r10800 19 Sep 13:00\) following cookie deletion, once during ordinary browsing \(although it took quite a long time for this to happen\) and once when attempting to post to a discussion forum. Interesting, the posting apparently actually went through, so the browser presumably crashed immediately afterwards\!

However I have not managed to induce a crash yet while not logged in.

I can supply my log-in details privately if this would help but obviously will not post them here.

tickets.description: Because cokie\_initialise is not used within the Framebuffer frontend, cookie\_tree\_root is NULL. But there is some callback scheduled after page load which does not check for this condition. When the callback get's executed, NetSurf crashes. One possible fix is to avoid the scheduling of the cookie update callbacks if cookie\_tree\_root is NULL.

tickets.description:
NetSurf 2.6 \(21-Sep-10; running on Iyonix/RISC OS 5.16/128MB RAM\) ignores the content-type information sent by the server and incorrectly interprets resources as HTML if the following two conditions hold:

a\) the resource is in a password protected directory
b\) the resource has not been downloaded in the current session yet

This problem is a regression from earlier versions. NetSurf 2.1 interprets the content-type correctly under the above conditions.

Test case:

http://www.mw-software.com/test/
User: test
Password: testtest

Click on the download link. The zip file is incorrectly interpreted as HTML and displayed in the browser window despite the server sending "content-type: application/zip". Other browsers interpret the content-type correctly, including earlier versions of NetSurf.

Now, try again but Shift-click on the download link. This time, the file is correctly downloaded as a zip file. Now, try again with a normal click on the download link. Now even that works correctly. So, at a guess, this problem does not occur if the file is already in the cache.

If the resource in question is a large zip file, trying to interpret it as HTML can have nasty effects, causing NetSurf to apparently lock up the machine.
tickets.summary: Binary downloads incorrectly interpreted as HTML

I thought this one had been cleared a long time ago, but it's either back again or still there.

A table inside a table cell with centre alignment \(e.g. a table header\) is not centered but left aligned. Within the table, the contents of data cells are centered when they should be left aligned. If the nested table cell contains an unordered list then the bullets are left aligned but the text of list items is centered. This probably applied to oiredered lists too but I haven't tried them.

posts.text: It looks like this might be specific to table header cells <th> as using a data cell plus a center tag works fine. I haven't tried align attributes yet.

Recently NetSurf has been throwing up spurious "NetSurf is running out of memory" messages even though there is 70-80MB of free memory. This happens in particular on the PayPal and Twitter sites. Clicking on "Continue" causes NetSurf to carry on normally.

tickets.description:
Had been testing NetSurf 2.6 for RISC OS on my Beagleboard-xM \(http://www.tankstage.co.uk/Beagle/ROM.zip\). I used the onboard NIC for the first time, using a pre-release version of EtherUSB. Configured my network settings manually. Everything fine at first. After a complete power off and restart though I was unable to start NetSurf. Deleting EtherUSB, Netsurf itself didn't chieve anything. Deleting all my network settings finally allowed me to start my newly installed Netsurf.
Choosing "via DHCP" seems to have solved the problem as everything seems to be fine again.
However the logfiles don't seem to mention network settings as the culprit.

posts.text: Treeview has since been replaced, so it's going to be impossible to determine the cause of this, and it's probably been fixed in the replacement.

tickets.description:
The problem page is this one:

http://www.kiwisbybeat.com/greatarchive.html

I first noticed an issue when I viewed it with NetSurf 2.6 ages ago.  At the time I thought, 'Bugger', and went and downloaded the latest development version to see if it had been fixed yet.  It had, so I didn't complain.

Or so I thought.

I've just viewed it under NetSurf 2.7, and it's back\!

So I went and downloaded the latest development version \(r12201\), and tried again.  Voila, as they probably say in foreign parts, the problem vanished.

The symptoms are this:

AFAICT, it's encoded in either UCS-2 or UTF-16, with every character taking two bytes.  In practice, this means every other byte is a zero.  Development builds fully support this, but release builds, for whatever reason, don't\!  The result is a page full of uninterpreted HTML source interspersed with blobby hex characters.

I've no idea what was different in the compiling process, but if ever there was a reason not to bother with so-called 'stable' versions, this would seem to be it.

RISC OS 5.16 on Iyonix.
tickets.summary: Unicode problem which ONLY manifests in release builds

posts.text: Will be fixed in the next stable release.

posts.subject: #1199 Unicode problem which ONLY manifests in release builds

tickets.description:
\(Copied from mailing list.  Written from perspective of RISC OS; Chris Young confirms the jumping to bottom of list bug is core.\)

Deleting cookies - any cookie - seems to be riddled with issues.

When I first select one and delete it \(via the toolbar or the menu\), the whole treeview flickers madly for a few seconds.  After that, the cookie disappears from view, but scrolling down to the bottom reveals it's only been moved to the last entry instead of being deleted.  Deleting it from its new position seems to work.

Deleting several cookies, either via the same delete operation or individually, results in them all being moved to the bottom.  However, subsequently deleting one which was initially moved there but has since been pushed up by further deletions works, rather than moving it a few entries back to the bottom, so it doesn't seem to be a purely positional thing.

\[Iyonix RISC OS 5.16\]

On both r12288 and r12380, the stability of the browser is significantly compromised.  The test version I had used before that was r12243, which AFAICR did not exhibit this bug.

The browser keeps stiffing the computer totally - hourglass running, but nobody home.  I can't find a specific cause, but it often occurs when closing browser windows.  Since installing r12288 and subsequently r12380, almost every NetSurf session has eventually been terminated in this manner, by means of Alt+Break.

On this particular occasion, I closed the last browser window, revealing the hotlist beneath.  I clicked on the collapse button for the level which was currently open, and the the top level \(its parent\).  Neither level collapsed, which is when I discovered the computer had locked up.  I mention this in case it's relevant \(by analogy to Windows stiffing if you click too fast\).

No log file crash report, because the program didn't trap the crash.  I have attached the final section of the log file it did leave behind, starting from the point when I opened the fateful window.

This is, needless to say, an extremely serious bug.

The post-Wakefield versions of Netsurf seem to have developed a trait of sometimes freezing up altogether when I click on the 'Stop' icon to abort a fetch and remain on the previous page \(typically after spotting a typo in a search term\). Alt-Break is required to regain control of the desktop, with the loss of data in all other open browser windows since no browser history is recorded.

No error log is generated, but I attach the end of the log from the latest occurrence, an aborted IMDb search for "Springtime in Bridland"\[sic\]

NB this may well be the same bug as \[3300525\] below, although the reported trigger seems different.


\(Edit: I have tried to submit this twice and received the error "XSRF Attempt Detected\!" - trimming log again.\)

harriet.bazley@blueyonder.co.uk

posts.text: It sems to get stuck at the 'Fetching, Processing' stage \(as opposed to the 'Fetching, Fetching, Processing' stage \(?loading CSS sheets?\) which normally follows this.

tickets.description:
There's a problem with drawing your scrollbars inside the boundaries of a fixed-size box - by definition, they make the box smaller.

See here for an example:

http://dandyforums.freeforums.org/post37.html\#p37

The vertical scrollbar overlaps the right-hand border of the image, but NetSurf doesn't detect that the display area is now so narrow a horizontal scrollbar is required.  Consequently, the rightmost column is invisible.

Having visited several websites, when I pressed Ctrl+Shift+W, to widen the view of one of them, NetSurf r12485 reported a serious error, and crashed. I believe that the website was that of Reuters, but I do not have its url. The NetSurf Log file is attached. Using: RO 6.20 on a RiscPC.

posts.text:
It's happened again, but this time I have a url:
http://www.ctv.ca/CTVNews/TopStories/20110616/hefner-harris-didnt-see-it-coming-110616/ Display the page then press Ctrl+Shift+W 
Please see attached Log2/zip

tickets.description:
Attempting to view any page on the Ravelry.com website will take you to the log-in screen  https://www.ravelry.com/account/login \(which is fair enough so far as it goes - this is a member-restricted site\), but the log-in then repeatedly fails. After supplying a valid name and password the requested original URL will appear in the URL bar briefly but the page is not rendered before you are once again returned to the log-in screen. \(If you supply an incorrect password there is no attempt to transfer to the requested URL, so the data is clearly being received and acted upon at the far end.\)

Once you do manage to get logged in \(I haven't managed to work out what triggers it\) you then have access to the whole site, with the absence of the JavaScript features, but cannot then log out.   This is less of a problem but still puzzling.

The log \(attached\) suggests that the problem is occurring somewhere around "Failed creating namespace" \(line 86 in log\)

posts.text:
The answer to logging-in is to deletes cookies, apparently \(I knew I'd done something or other in the past....\)

And the solution to the XSRF Netsurf/Sourceforge problem which prevents the posting of comments is still to log out of Sourceforge :-\(

Harriet
posts.author: nobody
posts.subject: #1214 Round in circles on log-in

posts.text: Actual content of cookies that prevent log-in (20 Sep 2011)
posts.author: harriet
posts.subject: #1214 Round in circles on log-in

posts.text:
Further to this: you have to open the login page \*before\* attempting to delete the Ravelry cookies - doing so 'in advance' doesn't work. Required sequence: display http://www.ravelry.com/account/login
Show cookies
Delete www.ravelry.com cookies
Log in
posts.author: harriet
posts.subject: #1214 Round in circles on log-in

posts.text: This is apparently a \[lack of\] JavaScript issue in addition to a cookies issue, since it is possible to log in to this site without prior cookie deletion using the test JavaScript version.

posts.subject: #1214 Round in circles on log-in

posts.text:
Addendum:  it is possible to log into the site using the test JavaScript version with Javascript \*disabled\*, but only on the ARMini. The identical version of Netsurf \(825 js-on\) running on the Iyonix requires the cookies to be deleted as previously.
\(RISC OS 5.19/5.18\)

Uploaded: logs of failed \(on Iyonix\) and succeeded \(on ARMini\) attempts to open http://www.ravelry.com and log in nusing same username and password.

tickets.description: On attempting to go from the front page to page 2 of the Lolcats site http://icanhascheezburger.com NS crashed immediately.  Iyonix, RO 5.16, 512 MiB, NS 12551.

NetSurf r12553 has developed severe issues with the HTML form upload field, erroring with a "failed creating formpost data" - but this only happens if you try to submit certain filetypes to certain forum engines.

I've confirmed it is impossible to submit zip files or text files to SMF-based forums, and it also appears impossible to submit \(at least\) text files to phpBB-based forums.  However, it is possible to submit PNGs to phpBB-based forums.  Which forum you use appears immaterial - it's the engine that matters.

I did manage to submit a text file to the Icon Bar forum, but this admittedly has a very different attachment mechanism, in which you have to first submit the post, then go back for another page in which the only form fields are the upload and the submit - so it may be to do with having a text box in the same form, or multiple action buttons.

I've attached a text file here to see if SourceForge does it as well.  \(Curse the lack of a preview button\!\)  CORRECTION: it does.  A bug report cannot be submitted with a text attachment.  Since this precludes attaching log files, you may want to look into this post-haste\!

posts.text:
Update: I've worked out what's causing it\!

It's nothing to do with the filetype, and everything to do with the filename.  If there is a top-bit set character anywhere in the filename or pathname \(in my case, it was a hard space\) then you get the "failed creating formpost data".  The PNG worked because it was in a different directory\!  This still doesn't explain how I successfully submitted a file located beneath a directory with a hard space in it to TIB though\!

tickets.description:
OK, a real textplain-related bug this time\!

If a browser window is open and displaying a web page, and you drag a text file into it \(under RISC OS\), NetSurf r12553 crashes \(log attached\).

If a browser window is open and displaying an image \(e.g. JPEG, PNG\) and you drag a text file to it, it displays correctly.

If a browser window is open and displaying a web page, and you drag an image to it, this also works, as does image-to-image.

If a browser window is open and displaying a text file, and you drag another text file to it, NetSurf crashes\!

Note: Dragging any file to the icon bar icon works as expected - the target has to be an open browser window.

tickets.description:
Over the last few weeks I have been getting the following error when visiting www.google.co.uk sometimes:

Warning from NetSurf
Failed writing body \(0 \!= 249\)
Continue

When I click continue the page remains blank.  When I click the Netsurf icon on the icon bar a second time, it usually works but sometimes it repeatedly fails to load with the same error every time.  I have only had this error with the Google page.  All other sites I have tried work OK as usual.

My telephone exchange has recently been upgraded to 21CN and my broadband connection has been upgraded to ADSL2+ a few weeks ago as well.  I don't know if there is a connection but the error and upgrade both started around the same time.

I am using an Iyonix PC with RISC OS 5.16 \(512MB memory\) with the latest stable NetSurf 2.7
I also have a Windows PC and www.google.co.uk has never produced an error on that.
tickets.summary: Netsurf 2.7 on Google 'Failed writing body' error

posts.text:
I have tried upgrading to the latest beta release - r12644 23 Aug 2011 - and
the problem remains.  It also happens occasionally on other websites, not just Google.  It goes wrong about 30 times a day for me at the moment and is a real pain.
posts.author: bapfish
posts.subject: #1221 Netsurf 2.7 on Google 'Failed writing body' error

posts.text: I also had this problem with the Atari port at the beginning. It was caused by an network bug within the kernel / socket API. The socket was reported to be writable right after connect\(\), which isn't correct - first it has to establish the TCP connection. If you write to the socket altough the connect\(\) isn't finished. you will get exactly this error.
posts.author: nobody
posts.subject: #1221 Netsurf 2.7 on Google 'Failed writing body' error

posts.text:
Thank you for taking the time to report this bug and helping to make NetSurf better. 
However, I am closing it because the bug seems to have been fixed in the latest development version of NetSurf.

Please, try to reproduce this bug using the latest version. If the bug still exists, feel free to file a new report with an updated version number.

tickets.description:
\[Iyonix RISC OS 5.16\]

This was supposed to be a repeatable bug.  It still happens most of the time, but not all the time.

The first log is of me going to <http://www.amigaremix.com> and clicking on the first MP3 link \(second column\) on the current front page \("Guitar Slinger"\), which is supposed to download the MP3.  In this case, it was at <http://www.amigaremix.com/listen/2502/Zzr%20-%20Guitar%20Slinger%20remake%202011.mp3>.  NetSurf segfaulted.  I successfully produced the same error on all attempts with r12624, r12633, r12664 and r12668.

So, after that I thought I'd get all smart and try to reduce it to a minimal test case.  The only unusual things I could see about the URL was that it was a binary file, and there were hex codes in its name, so I tried uploading a test binary file with hex codes in its name.  Much to my annoyance, NetSurf downloaded this perfectly.

Trying to figure out exactly what had gone wrong, I went back to the original file via the AmigaRemix front page \(so not a directly typed-in URL\)... which then proceeded to download perfectly.

In desperation, I quit NetSurf the normal way and clicked on a saved copy of the MP3 link above, causing NetSurf to load automatically in the process.  The file again downloaded perfectly.

Then, without quitting NetSurf, I went back to the AmigaRemix front page, where I had first observed the bug and which had worked on the last attempt.  I clicked the link and... whoops, it crashed.

The second log is of this last attempt, starting from the automatic load.

I hope I've managed to provide enough information to make this bug fixable, and that I'm not the only person who can trigger it.  It seems easiest to crash from a 'cold start' - i.e. not having viewed any other pages first - but bear in mind that the very first crash was at the end of an extended browsing session.  Also, as far as I can tell, it's impossible to crash without having clicked the link on the AmigaRemix site - all 'Open URL' attempts and link clicks in other applications so far have worked.
I want to build netsurf 2.7 with framebuffer frontend on gentoo system, but it needs xcb-util 0.3.6 which is incompatible with other programs that use 0.3.8. Update to libNSFB?

tickets.description:
I run Netsurf GTK from scratch \(GNOME launcher\), which displays the NetSurf home page \(netsurf-browser.org/welcome/\)
I type in a term into the Google search box to the right of the URL bar, let's say 'cheese', and press Return
That gives me Google's page of search results in a new tab
I click on the first one, which takes me to cheese.com
I click the back arrow on the NetSurf toolbar
This takes me back to the NetSurf home page, not back to the page of Google search results

Whenever I do a search from the search box and click on a search result, clicking 'back' takes me back to the page that was in the tab I had open when initiated the search, even though that page is still open in the original tab.  There's no way to get back to the list of search results.

NetSurf 2.7 \(7th April 2011\) on Debian Squeeze, .deb downloaded earlier this week:
-rw-r--r-- 1 atm26 atm26   962790 Apr 27 22:46 netsurf-gtk\_2.7-2\_amd64.deb
Linux eocene 2.6.32-5-amd64 \#1 SMP Wed May 18 23:13:22 UTC 2011 x86\_64 GNU/Linux

tickets.description:
NS r12872 \(RISC OS 5.16\) has some odd ideas about how this page should be laid out:

http://www.shortpacked.com/

A lot of the images appear to be overlaid on top of each other, and the horizontal navigation bar covers part of the comic image.

When scrolling up and down a page, NetSurf r12872 \(RISC OS 5.16\) frequently blanks out sections of the document which come into view, but then fails to redraw them.  The problem is intermittent and difficult to reproduce, but is very reminiscent of a similar redraw box-related scrolling bug which was fixed several months ago.

I don't guarantee results, but one page which seems to be suffering particularly badly is http://www.corporateskull.com/.  Casually dragging the vertical scrollbar downwards will usually result in the loss of a horizontal chunk out of the top picture in the current most recent blog post, "The end of Corporate Skull".

I've discovered a few other issues by accident while testing.  Clicking on a second NetSurf browser window which is behind the Corporate Skull one, keeping the Skull title bar visible, and then clicking the latter to bring the Skull window back to the front, will result in the entire formerly covered area of the Skull window being blank.  I tested this with the SourceForge 'Add Artifact' window I'm typing into, and I was unable to reverse the effect - i.e. to blank out the SourceForge window by opening, and then hiding, the Corporate Skull window in front of it.  I could, however, blank the Skull window by opening a StrongED window in front of it, although this took several attempts, suggesting either a very intermittent bug or one dependent on some uncontrolled third factor, e.g. dragging of NetSurf windows in the meantime. 

Dragging any other window over a blanked area will cause the redraw to be completed in the regions the dragged window leaves behind.  This also works with menus, including opening a menu over the NetSurf window itself.

tickets.description:
Material required for reproduction: Any multi-line text input box.  The ones on SourceForge will do just fine.

When typing into a text box and its height changes above its original maximum extent \(i.e. a scrollbar is present or newly created\), whether this be by having typed too much, or simply having pressed Return repeatedly, then in between the keypress which caused the height to change and the next one, the caret is wrongly vertically positioned.  The same symptoms occur whether the height increases or decreases, but if it increases, the caret is below the correct position, and if it decreases, it is above.  It is reset to its correct position on the next keypress.  The exact amount of error seems to vary according to the total extent, or possibly even just randomly.

The error doesn't occur if there is no vertical scrollbar in the text box either before or after the height change \(i.e. if the extent of the box is still the same, but some parts are off-limits to the caret\).  It does occur if a scrollbar is created or deleted in the process.  The actual vertical position of the caret is immaterial - it doesn't necessarily have to be at the bottom.

Tested, reproduced and confirmed on NetSurf r12872 \(RISC OS 5.16\), repeatedly, in this very text box, not always voluntarily.
tickets.summary: Caret position wrongly updated when text box height changes

tickets.description:
With RISC OS version 2.8 \(2.7 did not show this problem\). Go to Page entry of main menu, choose Find text, and then type a single character \(which exists on the page being viewed\) into the string box, the cursor jumps to the next occurrence of that character but the window vanishes. The main menu remains on view but with the Page entry greyed out. Therefore I cannot continue typing more than one letter, to search for a string. If the single typed character does NOT exist on the page, the window does not vanish, and it says Not Found at the bottom as expected. A work-around is to use the pop up history menu \(of search strings\). Once something has been selected from this list, the entry in the text box can be altered to add further characters until I've typed what I actually want to search for without the window disappearing.
Ewen Pring

tickets.description:
This happens on all recent versions of Netsurf I've tried, including the latest test build 13028.

To demonstrate the problem - download this file \(it's a large document from GameFAQs, about 1M in size\): http://www.gamefaqs.com/n64/197770-the-legend-of-zelda-majoras-mask/faqs/49987

Save the file to disc. Open it in Zap's text mode and remove all CR characters \(search for "\xd" and replace with ""\). Save under a different name.

Load the edited file into Netsurf - for me it takes about 55 seconds \(Iyonix RO 5.17\).

Compare with the time it takes Netsurf to display the original file - I got bored waiting after about 8 minutes.

tickets.description:
Hello,

Been trying to compile Netsurf \(stable 2.8 and yesterday's latest r13109 from svn\) for linux framebuffer frontend on an embedded Linux \(3.0.4 kernel & quite basic Busybox\) booting from PXE, running in a VMWare. Problem with both versions is that it almost immediately segfaults after launch, like this:

\[...\]
\(0.18172\) content/fetchers/curl.c fetch\_curl\_setup 359: fetch 0x8b9c738, url 'http://www.heise.de/'
\(0.18266\) framebuffer/fbtk/fbtk.c fbtk\_request\_redraw 106: redrawing 0x8b9b630 0,0 640,26
\(0.18278\) framebuffer/fbtk/fbtk.c do\_redraw 563: clipping 0x8b9aff0 0,0 800,600
\(0.18286\) framebuffer/fbtk/fbtk.c do\_redraw 563: clipping 0x8b9b0b8 0,0 800,30
Segmentation fault

I've pasted some more useful output into a Pastebin: http://pastebin.com/b44dHYss - Contained in there is an "fbset -i" \(just to show that the framebuffer is working - an ancient pre-compiled version 2.0 of Netsurf did in fact work nicely in that same environment\), my Makefile.defaults \(got rid of the references to Makefile.config\), the entire "netsurf -v -f linux" Output and an abbreviated ltrace and strace of that same command.

It \*appears\* to be a problem in fbtk's do\_redraw\(\) but I have no idea how to fix this or if it has something to do with my libs or whatever. The dependencies have been compiled with basic "make install" from svn on the dev-machine and only the libs which "ldd netsurf" told me have been copied to the target.

Any ideas?

Thanks already,
Andy

posts.text: PS: I don't know if Sourceforge sends out an e-mail when there's a reply here so in case they don't: djs@djs.lu it is.
posts.author: djsdjsdjs
posts.subject: #1258 Segfault in fbtk's do_redraw()

posts.text:
Ok, I was able to reproduce this bug with the latest r13112 on a freshly installed Debian 6.0.3 x64 \("Expert install", skipped the "Install packages" part entirely, so no X, no bloat, only very basic server installation\) running in VMWare 8.0.0.

Those commands have been executed after first login:

added "vga=788" to /etc/lilo.conf, ran lilo, rebooted

fbset -i

mode "800x600-75"
\# D: 48.001 MHz, H: 46.876 kHz, V: 75.121 Hz
geometry 800 600 800 600 16
timings 20833 96 32 16 4 96 4
rgba 5/11,6/5,5/0,0/0
endmode

Frame buffer device information:
Name        : VESA VGA
Address     : 0xd0000000
Size        : 1920000
Type        : PACKED PIXELS
Visual      : TRUECOLOR
XPanStep    : 0
YPanStep    : 0
YWrapStep   : 0
LineLength  : 1600
Accelerator : No

apt-get install make g++ libncurses5-dev ssh fbset subversion pkg-config libcurl4-openssl-dev libxml2-dev libpng-dev libjpeg-dev libmng-dev \(of course those were actually several separate apt-get commands but that shouldn't really matter\).

cd /home/

svn co svn://svn.netsurf-browser.org/trunk/netsurf

cd netsurf

mkdir libs

cd libs

svn co svn://svn.netsurf-browser.org/trunk/libparserutils
svn co svn://svn.netsurf-browser.org/trunk/libwapcaplet
svn co svn://svn.netsurf-browser.org/trunk/hubbub
svn co svn://svn.netsurf-browser.org/trunk/libcss
svn co svn://svn.netsurf-browser.org/trunk/libnsgif
svn co svn://svn.netsurf-browser.org/trunk/libnsbmp
svn co svn://svn.netsurf-browser.org/trunk/librosprite
svn co svn://svn.netsurf-browser.org/trunk/libnsfb

Then I cd'ed into each of those folders in that order, the "make install"s all finished without errors.

cd ..

make install TARGET=framebuffer \(all \(Make\)files left untouched\)

M.CONFIG: JPEG \(libjpeg\)        enabled       \(NETSURF\_USE\_JPEG := YES\)
M.CONFIG: JNG/MNG/PNG \(libmng\)  enabled       \(NETSURF\_USE\_MNG := YES\)
M.CONFIG: PDF export \(haru\)     disabled      \(NETSURF\_USE\_HARU\_PDF := NO\)
M.CONFIG: glibc internal iconv  enabled       \(NETSURF\_USE\_LIBICONV\_PLUG := YES\)
M.CONFIG: PNG/MNG/JNG \(libmng\)  enabled       \(NETSURF\_USE\_MNG := YES\)

tickets.description:
Hi, not sure if this is a Netsurf-specific or Beagleboard-specific problem. On my Iyonix using Netsurf 2.8, https://ibank.barclays.co.uk/olb/w/BasicAccessStart.do
is accessible but on my Beagleboard \(again Netsurf 2.8 with same settings as Iyonix\) the page times out. I've tried over a few days and always get the same result.
Any ideas?
thank
Chris.

posts.text:
This is not a bug in NetSurf. Please add the following to the User configuration file for the Internet stack:

\*sysctl -ew net.inet.tcp.rfc1644=0

tickets.description:
The NRE journey planner fails to format properly in NS. In fact the data input fields come out in a strange order so what look like the return journey date and time \(on the right\) are in fact for the outward journey. The "advanced search" link doesn't show up at all although it is present in the source.
I don't think this is a javascript issue.

http://www.nationalrail.co.uk/planmyjourney/

When dropping a file to file input located within an internal browser frame, the drop isn't recognized. 

Maybe the frontend \(atari\) isn't able to figure out the content at the drop position. Even when that's the case, this is caused because the core fails to report the correct content at that position.
tickets.summary: File input (drop file here) does not work within frames

posts.text: Atari front end should call browser\_window\_drop\_file\_at\_point\(\) instead of trying to handle drops itself.

tickets.description:
shift-clicking on a link to a local application directory, or plain directory, doesn't download the directory, as expected, but downoads an html file, which lists the contents of the directory. For further details please see the demo-file at http://oldcoaster.drobe.co.uk/local\_file\_download.zip

Tony

posts.text:
NetSurf is behaving exactly as intended here.

There is no concept of downloading a directory of files, only individual files.

When you shift click on a link it forces the download, rather than display of the link target.

So for a PNG, it forces a download for the PNG rather than displaying the PNG in NetSurf. Likewise, for a directory it forces the download of the page it uses to show the directory, instead of rendering it in NetSurf.

tickets.description:
NetSurf fails to interpret the following URI correctly:
http://guest@chrisy:guest1@webdav.mydrive.ch/public/test.txt

Instead of visiting webdav.mydrive.ch with a username of guest@chrisy, it tries to visit host chrisy.

URL-encoding the first @ makes NetSurf interpret the address as expected. ie. the following works where the above fails:
http://guest%40chrisy:guest1@webdav.mydrive.ch/public/test.txt

tickets.description:
There's a check in \!Boot that looks for SpriteExtend 1.50, and if found does \*ICONSPRITES on the alpha channel sprites.
However, the RISC OS Open version of SpriteExtend has now passed version 1.50, so when softloaded on something other than RISC OS 5 the alphachannel sprites are used and rejected - hence no icon.

I think the various RMEnsures need tightening up a bit, to look for whatever version of Select that change switched in, rather than doing "if not RISC OS 5 and SpriteExtend 1.50 then alphasprites".

Here, using RISC OS 4.02 and SpriteExtend 1.51.
tickets.summary: NetSurf has no icon (filer or iconbar)

posts.text: Sadly, the only way to do this is to write a chunk of BASIC which loads and verifies ASprites. If this fails, we assume alpha sprites aren't available and then do the OS version check.

tickets.description:
Netsurf 2.9 will output some characters as unicode which may be reasonable for displaying HTML, but inappropriate when used with a filename, which means the browser cannot find the file.

For example, a bullet symbol is legal in Risc OS filenames, and should be displayed in a hyperlink to that file as %8F, but Netsurf 2.9 changes this to %EF%BF%BD which is a unicode error code. This results in a 404 file not found message, especially when used for local browsing across a hard disc. Many other such characters will be adversely affected.

Tennant Stuart, tennant@orpheusmail.co.uk - see also the thread "Local browsing" on comp.sys.acorn.misc

posts.text:
I can now confirm that \*all\* characters in the ASCII range 128 to 255 are adversely affected, even when Netsurf uses a valid unicode value. This is because the file name is still corrupted.

For example, a filename containing the word resum \(the more modern term for a CV, and correctly spelt with an e-acute to avoid confusion with the verb "resume"\) is rendered by Netsurf 2.9 as resum%C3%A9 instead of resum%E9 as specified by HTML standards.

Of course, there will be many thousands of affected words in various European languages.
posts.author: nobody
posts.subject: #1329 bad unicode in filenames

posts.text:
Sorry, I forgot to sign the above comment, which is again

Tennant Stuart, tennant@orpheusmail.co.uk

I try to use NetSurf 1.2 \(22 Mar 2008\) from Ubuntu repo for Ubuntu 10.04... I try to change defaul fonts but it didn't help me with very poor rendering :-\(
It cut top part of first line of paragraph as is seen on attached screenshot. Also rendering of www.google.pl is too poor to use it. 

I'm sad because NetSurf looked to join small footpring of text-only browsers with standard GUI apperance.

tickets.description:
SARPC / RO 6.20 : RPCEmu089 / RO 4.39 : RPCEmu089 / RO 5.19 \(16-Jul-12\)
NetSurf \#417, \#461, \#488, \#520

http://uk.mc296.mail.yahoo.com/mc/showFolder?fid=Inbox&order=down&tt=1&pSize=100&ymv=0&.rand=685069059 is the url of my Yahoo webmail inbox.

Using NetSurf \#417, and earlier versions, it leads to a log-in page, then a page saying \(incorrectly\) that re-direction is not supported and, after re-direction, the inbox page. No problem.

However, using NetSurf \#461, and subsequent versions, after re-direction, a white page appears, containing only the single unicode character fffd in the top left corner.

Tony

posts.text: full save of inbox and html of blank page

commit e9b207c658b1771d7e208535017cbbf33d9e0cf8
Author: Michael Drake <tlsa@netsurf-browser.org>
Date:   Mon Oct 8 20:22:04 2012 +0100

Port urldb to nsurl.  Won't build since rest of NS needs ported to new urldb

\+ urldb API now takes URLs as nsurl, rather than string.
\+ urldb internally stores full URLs with nsurl ref.
\+ urldb internally stores schemes as lwc\_string.
\+ Load and save of cookies and URL file may be slower since
we now need to create a nsurl.
\+ Everything else should be faster, and there should be much
less allocating/freeing and much less parsing of the same
url over and over again.
\+ Updated urldbtest for new urldb API.
\+ urldbtest now cleans up at the end
\+ Added lwc\_string itterator to end of urldbtest
\+ Adding some broken URLs \(such as http:domain/\) will now
work, since nsurl fixes \(http://domain/\) them.

Author: Michael Drake <tlsa@netsurf-browser.org>

posts.author: old_coaster
posts.subject: #1349 Yahoo webmail problem

posts.text:
The attached file logs/zip contains Log\_417, Log\_461, Log\_1083\_jsoff and Log\_1083\_json, which are the logs of login attempts.

Using \#417, the login was successful. The other three led to the error 'BadType', and no login.

To produce each log, NetSurf was quit, and the old log deleted, before re-starting NetSurf and attampting to login to Yanoo Mail.
posts.author: old_coaster
